number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Modern looking CRPG with roots in the old school. Divinity Original Sin is a solid built RPG with plenty of things to do and see. I started the game as a Cleric and a Knight (vanilla pre made classes the game it self provided for me to choose), then spent the next 10 hours enjoying my self until i came to a place where i kept running my head into a wall.I tried to circumvent this by seeing if there where more quests that i could do, to make my character level grow a bit. But turns out there was nothing left for me to do at this point. So after 3 hours in the same fight i called it quits, and started over. This time i took what i knew from the 10 hours of gameplay and made more focused character by avoiding the vanilla templates that where provided for me to use.I made a custom Ranger and a custom Fighter. The Ranger is a flimsy character, but with a bow i could negate that a bit by staying back. So i focued here points in Dex. For here skills i went with 1 point in Scoundrel only for 2 abilities that i would use all the way to the end of the game. Invisibility and a skill that let me earn more action points for the next rounds. I also put a single point in Geomancer so that i could get the ability to summon a spider, which was also a skill that i used in 95% of all my combat scenarios. After those i never upgraded Scoundrel or Geomancer again and stuck with the Expert Marksman still to give me more abilities in the usage of Bows.The fighter was simple, i focused points in Constitution from the start giving me an edge in terms of HP. His ability points went into Shield specialist and Man at Arms. I wanted him to take all the damage, along with the spider summon.So again played for 9 hours saved some time because i remembered most of what i was supposed to do, got to the same spot, lost. Tried again with a different strategy and i was finally over that painful part. Now this was a fight that had a party of 4 VS. an enemy party of 7-8. The boss fight right after was easy and i almost lost no health what so ever. And this is one of my biggest issues with the game, sometimes you will encounter some very unbalanced fights that just seem there for the sake of making you miserable. Luckily i didn't find my self in that situation that many times, and if i lost the battle i usually had it the next try or the one after.But any how despite all that i loved the 83 hours i have spent on the game. The settings and graphics are so damn nice to look at, and exploring the world is very fun. The whole murder mystery that the game starts off with is without a doubt the best part of the games story. The story gets very dumb and convoluted after you leave the first major town. But that doesn't stop the gameplay from still being very enjoyable and fun.I recommend this game to any one who likes old school RPG games. But i urge every one to focus their stats into a few key areas, if you spread your points out too much you will gimp your character, and make it frustrating and a bad experience. Do not pick any of the pre made classes, customize them and focus on what you want to be doing with that character. Maybe even look up a guide on how to set up some points.ProsTactical combat really fun and robustElemental combat scenariosPlenty of places to spend skill pointsGraphics and art style are gorgeousGood ambient and combat soundsBig variety in skills and magicConsStupid enemy AIUneven fights that result in hair lossVery limited look to armors and weaponsRepetive NPC dialoguePossible to create broken charactersDistribution of loot quality and unusable gear can be a blessing and a curse. Most often the latterStory loses its appeal after the first major townCompanions are very shallow in terms of character developmentFinal boss fight is infuriating and cheapOver all great game. And one i won't forget.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												This is a game with the spirit of the classic RPGs but a modern design and technology. So far I love it and I highly recommend it. GameplayThis is where Divinity: Original Sin really shines the most, in my opinion. There is a very interesting system that makes elements interact with each other. Is your character burning or reluctant to pass through a flake of poison? Cast a rain spell to dissipate these elements. But beware, everybody will become wet and thus will be more vulnerable to air and water spell. That means they can get frozen or electrified (stunned) more easily. The engine also allows stuff like action happening in different places with different characters simultaneously. For example, you could split your party in two to attempt a flanking manoeuvre, or solve a puzzle that requires multiple actions at the same time.Coop is great in this game. You can play with a friend, and not only you can take advantage of the two points aforementioned, but you also have a coop dialogue system. You and your friend (or stranger) play one of the two main characters, and you don't have to agree on everything. You can resolve conflicts with your charisma stat and a rock paper scissor game. Depending on the sentences you choose, you will get attributes points, like Compassionate or Heartless, which will give you opposite bonuses. So choose well.GraphicsThe game is quite sexy and is above the average for such RPGs. You can zoom and tumble the camera to see it better, and apart from a few blurry rock textures here and there, I have nothing to criticize. The effects of the elements in combat are quite beautiful, for instance the reflections when a surface is frozen. But don't get too distracted or you might slip on the ice.SoundThe music is generally good, sometimes original and the themes are quite memorable. I can remember some of the tunes when not playing the game.There are voice overs and they are of good quality as well (can't say for other languages though). The sounds effects are good to very good. The ambient sounds really help to bring you more immersion.Story / WritingAlthough English is not my native language, I can say that the writing is really good. The language there is quite elevated, and it's pleasant to read. There is a lot of humor, and characters have some depth, even the cheese merchant with his cheesy pick up lines :) The Story is good so far, although not super original (you're gonna save the world once again). But the quests and dialogues, coupled with the graphics, sound and gameplay, are good enough to guaranty a total immersion and many hours of enjoyable gameplay (even more if you can bring a friend along).There is also a level editor shipping with the game, so keep an eye for (potentially awesome) player content in the future.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												What a stunning achievement from a former Kickstarter.  Aces across the board.The graphics are nice and the environment is both beautiful as well as interactive, as during combat you can add water, fire, smoke, steam, and other effects to change the tide of battle.  These effect sight lines and cause damage.The combat is turn-based and full of great magical spells.  I also enjoy having to balance healing with aggression.There are 12 classes, but each is very customizable. There are many unique abilities, skills, attributes, and crafts for you to play around with.This is an old-school RPG game, so expect 15 hours of walking and talking to citizens before you hit level 4 -- at which point you will have enough skill and companions to survive a fight.  Also, you can kite enemies back to the guards or into areas full of traps to gain advantages.There are TONS of items in the game, but most you'll never use and most you'll sell.  There seems to be a finite amount of gold in this world, and I've collected what feels like most of it.  Second reroll = 18hrs = 23K.  Don't buy anything; play for long enough and it will drop (except for pants; none of my people have pants and I don't know why).Lots of treasure chests to dig up.Each combat area gives you a different feel with different challenges.The story is a ton of fun, though it get's a little weird when they added all the outerspace stuff.  So that part I didn't like.  But the main plot is about murder with a twist and I like that.I can't tell you how much I enjoyed this game -- first in beta and now live.  It's a must own for the RPG crowd and here's hoping they decide to make a sequel.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												So, now that I beat the game, time to review !TL;DR: + turn based tactical combat+ elemental synergy+ eye candy+ you actually have to think a bit and use common sense. No more blindly following the big arrow on the screen, you'll have to look for clues and read books+ 80-100h to beat+ number of skills+ secondary quests- difficulty drop at mid-game. Once you understand buff/debuff and have a basic sense of tactic, It gets easy. - the inventory - lack of companionsSo, I recommend this game. I backed it on kickstarter, and I do not regret it. The game, in its mechanics, is challenging, and far from the current videogame standards. You will have to consults your quests journal, use common sense to resolve puzzles (they are not that difficult really, except when you have to look for a *******ing button hidden in shadows or behinda leaf) , look for clues, read every piece of paper or book you find. No quest markers, If you don't know what to expect, you can feel a bit lost there. Combats are great. Really. a bit hard at the beginning. You really have to pay attention to things like initiative, speed, perception, how 2 spells will work together ... It is really a pleasure to begin some chain reaction when combining different elements. Unfortunately, once you understand how it works, how you can buff/debuff, use initiative order and combine elements, you are pretty unstoppable. There is a huge drop in difficulty at mid game. Even the end boss was more "long to kill" than "hard to kill" . It can make the game a bit borng, because the main storyline, is not really that interesting (I did not say it sucks , but it's average) Concerning the 2 main characters: I liked the rock/paper/scissors system used here, and how you can make your characters disagree on anything :d A word on crafting: depending on your mele/casting orientation it can be useful. There are a lot of recipe that can help at the beginning of the game, but mostly, at some point, you only use it to craft mage skillbooks and add resistance to your equipments. The mechanic is interesting and relies on logic (combining item to create stuff, like "I use my dagger to sharpen this branch, I get a stake) but it comes with a price: the inventory is not really practical, as everything can be an ingredient for crafting (but you get used to it) NB: I did not test co-op

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Has a cat romance quest, 10/10.Seriously, though, Divinity: Original Sin, is one of the finest RPGs I have ever had the pleasure of playing. Clever writing (though, the constant talking of the NPCs in the town can get annoying, they have a tendency to talk over each other), a quite pleasing art style and more stats and skills than you can shake a wizard staff at! Having the two main characters interact is also a great roleplaying mechanic, either with a friend, or even alone.The combat, especially, is a real treat. Turn-based, eschewing mana or other resources in favour of an Action Point system, a la the old X-COM. Enemies are tough and their favourite past-time is chopping adventurers to bits, so you'll need to use your skills intelligently, especially considering magic and their assorted elemental combos.Overall, a few minor nuisances here and there aside, Original Sin is a splendid game, well worth your time, especially if you feel casting cold spells in the rain should do more than just increase damage.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Baldur's Gate with a splash of XCOM. Linear and not particularly repeatable, but a good co-op diversion with a dedicated partner.No cover drawn from its XCOM heritage, but tactical combat control and lockdowns are the order of the day. Scoundrels, Men at Arms, and Expert Marksmen are effectively 'mages in armor', with broad spell variety saved for dedicated INT casters, who will have a few skill trees due to less attribute dependence. Spend some time studying the character generation and level up systems, as understanding how tightly you will need to specialize is vital - the game is parsimonious with stat improvements. The tactical combat will pull no punches though the AI can sometimes be baited into foolish mistakes of positioning. Get friendly with your quicksave key, and put a grin on - the combat can be brutal, and a winning contest can go south quickly when new enemy abilities make their first appearance. D:OS won't warn you about what's coming.For mages doing damage, elemental combinations are the order of the day, and being able to apply all of the earth(poison)/fire and water/air(electricity) pairings is useful, but specialize in one pairing. Countering these works as you might imagine - water dries up when heated, fire goes out when rained upon. Be able to counter them all, amongst your group. Poison can be burned off (explosively!). Ice will melt, faster with help. Witchcraft is the INT caster version of Man-at-Arms, with fewer controls, but more ranged debuffs and pet summons - an armored decapitator appearing behind enemy lines is nothing to sneer at. (Nor are the various elementals and animals from the elemental skills, for that matter, but one summon per caster at a time.)The writing is adequate, but not stellar. The first who-dun-it wasn't particularly inspiring, and oftentimes progression has been a matter of "what level are those enemies?" rather than a cohesive sense of direction and progress. The quest journal is next-to-useless for many quests, providing little or no information to follow up. Use markers liberally, and don't be ashamed to augment the game's lacking journalling with some of your own. If you're doing every quest, expect to either miss a few things or need a walkthrough/guide from time to time.The rock-paper-scissors mechanic for the 'persuasion minigame' is by turns novel and tiresome. It's cute the first couple of times you see it, and it's a new way to 'randomize' a mechanic that no one seems to get right (persuasion) but it misses the mark in not having an "autoplay". Frankly, I don't want to play RPS against the computer, or my partner, and if the point is to provide some uncertainty to 'speech checks', that's fine - but I don't care for the minigame much. Fortunately, it's been relatively rare thus far...Character control is relatively straightforward - two players control four characters between them, in any combination. The host controls who gets to run which, allowing one player to AFK while the other plays a combat or to allow a tactical novice to mind only a single character in combat, etc. Wife and I split our characters into two teams of two, and it works out well - I run the NPC warrior Madora (man-at-arms) and shadow cleric (witchcraft/some water/man-at-arms), she handles the mage duties (one in all colleges for access, specializing earth/fire for stronger effects) and the sneaky rogue Wolgraff we recruited.Combat is turn based and is the real meat of the game, with players asked to deploy skills and weapons to defeat foes in a number of varied battlefield conditions. Often, a different approach or tactical plan is the difference between victory and reloading, and fights have been challenging often.All around, an enjoyable game, but remember those roots - the game doesn't pretend to be a more modern RPG, no matter the pretty graphics, so study up on how the level system works. It doesn't pretend to have autopilot combat, either. Bring your tactical thinking to the table....and get ready to read, because this is a long, slow march, not a sprint.Edit:Bugs, however, abound. Often, we notice desync issues when the host reloads the game and player #2's characters appear to have no stats (base scores all reset to 5) and not be wearing their gear, etc. We've not experienced any corruption from these episodes, but save often to avoid screams of hair-rending frustration when player 2 says "My character is bugged. Again." I'm amazed this wasn't caught and corrected, given how prevalent it's been for us!We've seen a couple of minor oddities (one bug involved a repeatedly-exploding poison gas trap that killed a boss in a single round because the poison would detonate, leave a fire puddle, the gas would refill the area, detonate... The boss standing in the cloud never took a combat turn - the explosion cycle took himn from 100% to 0% in one round of chained, buggy explosions (not that I'm complaining).Learn how to temper armor and weapons, learn how to make basic equipment (Madora makes a decent smith) and you can take advantage of movement speed penalty reductions on heavy armor and enhanced basic damage on weapons (for free). Don't play 'hard mode' if you don't have to!If you're into RPGs this one's worth a look, but don't expect all the rough corners to be filed down or a 100% bug-free experience, because they're not and it's not.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												This is a great old-school rpg that, surprisingly, becomes much more fun when played with a friend. While most people will be content leading their parties of four on their own, the game opens up when you split the group and let someone else control a pair of characters. This seems like a scary prospect at first, but thankfully D:OS deftly avoids most co-op/multiplayer rpg annoyances. Any character can receive or turn in a quest on the party's behalf. Swapping loot between characters is a breeze (no more dropping items on the ground). The already tactical turn-based combat becomes even more complex and gratifying when you and a friend can each take a pair of characters, discuss your plan of attack, and watch the sparks, steel, fire, poison, and ice fly. Speaking of combat...well, I could talk about the combat all day. Each character takes a turn to move or perform an action, and everything that a character does costs action points (including changing gear in the middle of a battle). Unused action points can be carried over into the next turn if saved, which allows you to bank points for more expensive skills or certain sequences of actions. The various skills in D:OS come with surprising amounts of pros and cons. Your piercing ice attack may  shoot through and freeze multiple enemies, but anyone killed by the attack leaves behind an icy surface that will cause anyone who walks over it to slip and fall for several turns. Your fire attacks can trigger explosives or ignite clouds of poison, creating massive conflagrations in the blink of an eye; however, if you're not careful, you may end up seriously hurting your melee characters in the process. Rain spells will put out fires on the ground and on characters but will also leave everything on the screen more vulnerable to ice and lightning attacks.I don't really have many complaints about this game. There is a lot to discover in the land of Cyseal, and the game does not hold your hand outside of a few UI and gameplay tooltips here and there. Quests will not be marked on your map. You will have to carefully read npc dialogue and review the entries added to your journal in order to know where to complete and turn in quests. Your characters will frequently discuss things among themselves, and you are able to role-play their responses  in order to affect their dispositions towards each other, actions taken by the group, and even certain ideas (two of the companions you can pick up early on are very vocal about hating certain things). If you want to venture out into the wilderness and fight fire skeletons that are two levels above your characters, you are free to do so. You may be victorious, or your party might be reduced to four piles of ash within a turn. Everything is up to you, and at the end of the day, that is precisely what an rpg should be about.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Think how great it would be if you had some kind of insane mashup of Baldur's Gate and Divine Divinity. Now treble it, throw in a healthy dose of Larian's usual tongue in cheek humour, and you're looking at Original Sin.  Beginning with two characters (with more NPC's available to recruit along the way) you're a pair of source hunters (think witch finder♥♥♥♥♥inquisition) dispatched to investigate a murder. Though as usual, things aren't quite what they seem, what with the mysterious undead horde at the gates and constant attacks by an Orc invasion fleet.  Combat is turn based and thankfully manages to remain interesting. All combatants act according to an initiative order, with a reserve of action points they can use for clobbering, shooting or spell slinging. What's likely to garner most attention here is the environmental effects - create a poison cloud to gas your foes, then ignite it with a fireball to set them ablaze for good measure. Then douse them with water, which puts out the fire but creates a cloud of blinding steam instead. A cloud which can be electrified to bring a shocking conclusion to the fight.  Dialogue is your good old fashioned multi-choice dialogue tree. Your party members will chime in frequently when certain events happen, both within the party and without.  For your two initial characters you can choose their responses to each other, which seems weird but works quite well. Conversational skills are handled via a mini-game of rock-paper-scissors (though this is skippable) with the character's various skills impacting how this plays out.  The little touches are great; enter sneak mode for example and your character will pull off the old 'walking bush' trick with whatever seems to fit the environment. The screen fades slightly with character's vision cones highlighted so you can try and avoid whoever you're trying to sneak up on from spotting you. The ability to move objects within the world is put to good use in some of the puzzles and offers an interesting means of dealing with things like traps.  Writing so far is fantastic, with Larian's tongue being firmly in their cheek. Three hours in and I'm dressed as a barrel trying to pickpocket the commander of the city guard so I can steal his handkerchief to take to a dog I met in the graveyard so it can tell me if he's involved in his master's murder. This is after I've returned a talking clam to the sea and been transported through time and space to meet the weaver of time who'd quite like some help dealing with the final death of the universe. Never mind RPG of the year, this is probably my RPG of the previous decade.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												This game is one brilliant adventure in the colorful world of Rivellon. Somehow it combines aspects of the old games(like Planescape) and trends of today(and none of the bad ones). It starts slow, and the wheel of the story starts spinning faster and faster. And you want to follow it, faster and faster, but only to stop and take a look at the beauty of the world that Larian created. After that, you come back to the story, only to find the countless solutions to your problems and this diversity continues to prevail even in the batttle system. Nearly everything in this game shows you the amount of love that was put in it. But ofcourse you will stumble on one or two bugs, or even some moments in the side quests that will make you raise your eyebrow. But those moments are so sparse, that they just can't ruin your experience. And I must warn you, if you played mostly in recent RPG's(like I did sadle, because my Planescape/BG/NWN playthroughs were so long ago), you may loose yourself in the freedom and the amount of choices that you will be granted. I was so used to hand holding, that I got lost at the start, not knowing where to go, but as soon as I realized - "Hey, this is a true RPG, go on, have fun", I started to enjoy it more and more. But what really, really sweeten this experience for me, was that I got to fully enjoy this with my wife. Co-op is done brilliantly, so it just amplifies your journey. So all in all, if your looking for something fun and entertaining, go for this game, it's a gem, one we haven't seen in a long time.If you're more into the "list" type of reviews, then here it goes:Pros:+ Vast world+ Finite enemy encounters -> Finite experience -> your charcter build actually matters+ Co-op (2 player)+ Engaging story+ Engaging side quests(they finally matter)+ Turn-based Combat mechanic where surroundings and wheather matter+ Huge number of skills/spells, combined usage of which can be used to great advantage+ Beautiful art/world+ Variety of actions that you can perform and how you can solve problems+ Larian humorCons:- 4 Player Co-op supported only through mod(as of 4th of September 2014)- In co-op, if you're not sitting next to each other, reading dialogues that your partner is having, will be difficult sometimes (The time that it's above their heads is very little, and reading it from a log is nor very comfortable).- Appalling rock/paper/scissors which you need in some instances.- Few bugs here and there- Not enough consistency in some side quests- Combat is obligatory (not like Planescape where you can go through the game engaging only in 4 battles).

Early Access Review
								Me and me mate have been twiddling our thumbs since we finished NWN2 and BG2 before that, wasting our money on wanna be rpgs, but behold whats this Divinity Original Sin?, could this be the game we have been waiting for? 30 hours or so into it and several toon experimentations, RELEASE IT NOW!! darn you, we want to play the full version :).Graphics are nice, AI is very good on mobs but the bosses could use a tweek i think, loving the fast leveling i think that is bang on and the personality bonuses you get from interacting with npc's is a great touch. The game doesent hold your hand with silly quest markers which i also think is great, you can just roam around bumping into monsters and eventually you will find the quest update. Also you can pick a rdy made character class and edit it to your play style which is another lovely touch.This game could be the next BG2 or NWN, will have to wait till full realease to experience all game content but so far im hooked. Only negative i would say is only up to 2 players for co-op.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												[Please note: I reserve to change this review as I proceed in the adventure and as game patches come in].Divinity: Original Sin is a solid classic-style RPG, focused on co-op play (but absolutely enjoyable in solo play as well) with very modern graphics and with *lots* of things to do. A first thing to consider: this game is hard if you compare it to most contemporary titles -- you will die multiple times if you are not careful, trust me, so save often! -- and it does not take you by hand, it lets you explore the world and do what you like, when you like it; it feels old-school in a way, but at the same time extremely fresh. And speaking of it, the game world is enormous and should provide from 60 to 100 hours of fun, even without considering any of the user generated content that fans will provide on the Steam Workshop.The levelling system is classless so you can literally become anything you like (although the game delivers tens of starting archetypes if you don't want to mess too much with all the traits and abilities): for example, you can start as a warrior and acquire magical skills later in the game as you level up and assign points accordingly.Combat is tactical and turn-based and therefore quite complex... but don't worry, it's fun and you can plan your next move without being in a hurry!The post-launch lack of "AI personalities" for your party members has been fixed, and therefore now in singleplayer you can enjoy dialogues and banter with your own party members without having to pick all lines for everybody. :POverall I'm very impressed with this game, and I am looking forward to play it for much time to come. If you like CRPGs like me... get it, you won't be disappointed.My vote: 9 / 10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin is reminiscent of Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Neverwinter Nights, and all those great D&D based games from the 90's. The only difference is the turn based combat which doesn't detract from the game itself. I myself dislike turn based combat, but found that in Divinity, the combat was a very entertaining aspect.In the above list of games, if you spent time pausing combat, planning moves and then executing them, then Divinity: Original Sin will handle that just fine with it's turn based combat. The isometric (yes, isometric) views are gorgeous, and you can zoom in and get pretty up close and personal with the rest of the world. Speaking of views, you can disable it and have a full 360 view, but the main campaign doesn't recommend it due to, "graphical artefacts". However, when player made campaigns get released, they will hopefully make full use of the 360 immersion.Gameplay wise, the world is immersive and expansive. Characters are rather believable, and the choices you make do impact the rest of the world. I have yet to experience these choices, but my gut feeling tells me that some of the people I helped, shunned or let go will come back to haunt me in the future. At some points, you'll get inter-party conversations, which are nice, but some of them add a little twist to the gameplay. Depending on your choices, characters will gain trait points which can apply different bonuses to your character, or party. For instance, if you have a person who demonstrated good leadership, they'll inspire the rest of your team. However, if a conversation later down the line makes that same character act like less of a leader, they can lose that leadership trait.The game world is both expansive and immersive. The nice paintings in people's houses are very decorative... and profitable. A quick sleight of hand, and practically every object can belong to you. Broomsticks turn into weapons, buckets turn into helmets, pillows can be cut open and their feather's taken. Barrels and boxes can be moved to create some barricades to help with a battle, or to block traps. The amount of detail put into the environment and how you interact with it is astonishing. If you were like me, and were awaiting a game to astound and captivate you like Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale, Divinity: Original Sin won't disappoint. So far, everything in the game has been executed very well and has been polished rather nicely. I'm looking forward to delving further into the game world, and then experiencing it with online with other players.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Excellent game, though a bit tedious near the end. This is a *must-buy* game for people who enjoyed games like Jagged Alliance 2, Planescape: Torment, and Baldurs Gate as a kid. Graphics and sound effects are great and the music is good, about what you would expect, however there was not enough combat music diversity in my opinion.Great writing and story, albeit a bit predictable. Content wise, the game is as long as 4 games. Each big area is almost like game in itself by today's standards. About 90 hours in and I still havent finished it. For $40 USD you definitely get your moneys worth.My main complaint is the UI. Some other gripes I have is that the game is more linear than I would have liked. It is about on the same level as Planescape:Torment in that the story is definitely on rails.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Just when I was afraid that the RPG genre was dead from developers trying to make things over-accessible and simplified, this gem came along. If you love RPGs, especially turn-based, don't hesitate to pick this up. Here's everything you should know about the game to be an informed buyer. These aren't all bad things, just tips to make the best decision possible when buying this game: 1. The game uses a turn-based action point combat system. If you're looking for pure action, look elsewhere; there's lots of dialogue and some interesting puzzles, etc. (all of which are well done). However, there are some rather interesting (and unique) mechanics for stealth that allow you to move around the battlefield undetected; and while the fight is going on, you're not hindered by the typical action point system.2. This game does have spoken dialogue, but most of it is going to be in the form of text. This doesn't bother me, and the dialogue is very well done in both forms. 3. The game is not forgiving; save often. You can mess up quests and never be able to finish them on that playthrough, or you might have to do things in a different way. 4. The game, as of this review, still has bugs; another reason to save often. However, the developers are actively working to fix them, and are doing a fantastic job.5. The terrain is a huge part of combat in this game, and manipulating it by catching it on fire, putting fire out with a rainstorm, covering the field with toxic ooze, etc. is both common and extremely satisfying.If you're on the fence, I have one suggestion: Buy it. I can't recommend this game highly enough. The game is great single-player, but also shines in co-op and is an absolute blast with a friend. If you're looking for a great RPG, do yourself a favor. Scroll up right now and click "buy now." You'll be glad that you did.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Baldur's Gate with a splash of XCOM. Linear and not particularly repeatable, but a good co-op diversion with a dedicated partner.No cover drawn from its XCOM heritage, but tactical combat control and lockdowns are the order of the day. Scoundrels, Men at Arms, and Expert Marksmen are effectively 'mages in armor', with broad spell variety saved for dedicated INT casters, who will have a few skill trees due to less attribute dependence. Spend some time studying the character generation and level up systems, as understanding how tightly you will need to specialize is vital - the game is parsimonious with stat improvements. The tactical combat will pull no punches though the AI can sometimes be baited into foolish mistakes of positioning. Get friendly with your quicksave key, and put a grin on - the combat can be brutal, and a winning contest can go south quickly when new enemy abilities make their first appearance. D:OS won't warn you about what's coming.For mages doing damage, elemental combinations are the order of the day, and being able to apply all of the earth(poison)/fire and water/air(electricity) pairings is useful, but specialize in one pairing. Countering these works as you might imagine - water dries up when heated, fire goes out when rained upon. Be able to counter them all, amongst your group. Poison can be burned off (explosively!). Ice will melt, faster with help. Witchcraft is the INT caster version of Man-at-Arms, with fewer controls, but more ranged debuffs and pet summons - an armored decapitator appearing behind enemy lines is nothing to sneer at. (Nor are the various elementals and animals from the elemental skills, for that matter, but one summon per caster at a time.)The writing is adequate, but not stellar. The first who-dun-it wasn't particularly inspiring, and oftentimes progression has been a matter of "what level are those enemies?" rather than a cohesive sense of direction and progress. The quest journal is next-to-useless for many quests, providing little or no information to follow up. Use markers liberally, and don't be ashamed to augment the game's lacking journalling with some of your own. If you're doing every quest, expect to either miss a few things or need a walkthrough/guide from time to time.The rock-paper-scissors mechanic for the 'persuasion minigame' is by turns novel and tiresome. It's cute the first couple of times you see it, and it's a new way to 'randomize' a mechanic that no one seems to get right (persuasion) but it misses the mark in not having an "autoplay". Frankly, I don't want to play RPS against the computer, or my partner, and if the point is to provide some uncertainty to 'speech checks', that's fine - but I don't care for the minigame much. Fortunately, it's been relatively rare thus far...Character control is relatively straightforward - two players control four characters between them, in any combination. The host controls who gets to run which, allowing one player to AFK while the other plays a combat or to allow a tactical novice to mind only a single character in combat, etc. Wife and I split our characters into two teams of two, and it works out well - I run the NPC warrior Madora (man-at-arms) and shadow cleric (witchcraft/some water/man-at-arms), she handles the mage duties (one in all colleges for access, specializing earth/fire for stronger effects) and the sneaky rogue Wolgraff we recruited.Combat is turn based and is the real meat of the game, with players asked to deploy skills and weapons to defeat foes in a number of varied battlefield conditions. Often, a different approach or tactical plan is the difference between victory and reloading, and fights have been challenging often.All around, an enjoyable game, but remember those roots - the game doesn't pretend to be a more modern RPG, no matter the pretty graphics, so study up on how the level system works. It doesn't pretend to have autopilot combat, either. Bring your tactical thinking to the table....and get ready to read, because this is a long, slow march, not a sprint.Edit:Bugs, however, abound. Often, we notice desync issues when the host reloads the game and player #2's characters appear to have no stats (base scores all reset to 5) and not be wearing their gear, etc. We've not experienced any corruption from these episodes, but save often to avoid screams of hair-rending frustration when player 2 says "My character is bugged. Again." I'm amazed this wasn't caught and corrected, given how prevalent it's been for us!We've seen a couple of minor oddities (one bug involved a repeatedly-exploding poison gas trap that killed a boss in a single round because the poison would detonate, leave a fire puddle, the gas would refill the area, detonate... The boss standing in the cloud never took a combat turn - the explosion cycle took himn from 100% to 0% in one round of chained, buggy explosions (not that I'm complaining).Learn how to temper armor and weapons, learn how to make basic equipment (Madora makes a decent smith) and you can take advantage of movement speed penalty reductions on heavy armor and enhanced basic damage on weapons (for free). Don't play 'hard mode' if you don't have to!If you're into RPGs this one's worth a look, but don't expect all the rough corners to be filed down or a 100% bug-free experience, because they're not and it's not.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin has two very big thumbs up from me.  It's one of the best RPG's I've played in a long, long time. That said, there certainly are a few issues which I'm sure will be remedied over time.  The responsiveness and care that Larian has put into the release and post release of this product is second to none.The freedom that the player has while clumsily wandering throughout the very large and immersive world is unparalleled.  Being able to do whatever I want, whatever I want - good or bad is powerful.  That kind of freedom really allows the player to be a part of the world and really drive where the game goes (or doesn't go).Aside from some intrusive tutorial stuff and some weird UI management - the game is pretty spectacular.  I know I'll be playing it for a while to come and I've already sunk over 90 hours into it.

content:

Early Access Review
								I loved the concept of Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights, but I could never get into that style of gameplay (even though I'm a hardcore KotOR fan). This game does an excellent job of delivering an RPG with elements very much like the classic Bioware titles and mixes in some contemporary features (but just enough to stay true to the old genre). Excellent graphics, witty dialogue (and there's a lot of it, even for it being currently in Beta), smooth combat (a bug here or there as expected), and a smack of nostalgia makes this game fit quite well in the hands of a player who spends far too much time in Elder Scrolls games. You want open-ended story with complex character crafting? Grab this. Grab the two originals as well.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Divinity Original Sin is old-school-style RPG, with a rich atmosphere, lots of character-building, turn-based combat and excellent coop-support where you (or you and a friend) play as the two main-characters, called the "source-hunters".TLDR-version: I definitly recommend this game to all non-casual RPG fans, for it highly depends on much reading and using ones own wits to solve or even find quests.[4/5] Gameplay The gameplay as it is would be perfect. You have interesting combat (more on that later), trading and dialouge options with almost every character in the world, a gripping story and huge freedom in terms of character-building. Battle-mage that vanishes like a rouge during combat? No problem. The typical grumpy, know-it-all wizard with devasting spells? Of course. A weak charismatic healer with almost no combat skills? Here you go.There regullary are dialouges between the two heros, where you can define their attitude towards each other and their nature.So the observing reader may ask: Why only 4 out of 5 stars? Well the gameplay experience is hindered by some bugs from time to time (not that often). There is for example a bug, that lets the attributes and breastplate of your controlled hero disappear (only on your client). The host has to save the game and reload it to fix it. Or there is this bug that prevent you from hitting enemies that are to close to rocks or walls (only had this bug twice in my playtime).With these bugs fixed the gameplay would be perfect.[5/5] Combat The combat is round-based. Normally I prefer real-time combat over turn-based, but Divinity: Original Sin is an exception I guess. The combat is incredibly complex (yet easy, don't get me wrong!), so the turn-based system lets you use the terrain and fight very strategicaly. There are tons of different spells and lots of different weapon styles. You can (with the right talent) backstab enemies for extra damage or create a oil surface and inflame that, teleport an enemy into that burning surface, electrify water sufaces or steam-clouds, the possiblities are endless.[4.5/5] Controls Not much to say about the controlls. One could say good controlls don't come to your attention and that's the case here. The game is mainly controlled with the mouse, though there are shortcuts for the spells in your hotbar, the inventory...The only problem that occured to me is that when you try to get some item out of an poisoned/burning/electrified area and you can't reach it from out of that area, your hero steps into it and (especially in the begining of your journey) dies. So you have to be careful...[3.5/5] AIThe AI in this game controlls your character when you are walking by clicking on the ground instead of holding the left mouse button to guide him or her. It does a decent job at that, avoiding hazardous areas or traps, as long as it is able to (see "controlls").The AI of enemies on the other hand somtimes is quite dumb. For example: It attacked my main character until he had 20hp left. Now it could have killed him with another successful hit. Instead it started attacking my companions and ended up losing that fight.Sometimes I'm quite thankful for quirks like that, for the fights can be really hard from time to time, yet it feels "wrong", if you know what i mean.Often the AI beautifully combines spells and terrain effects, creating challenging fights without feeling unfair. Many times there was that "WTF?!" effect when an enemy shot an poison arrow at my group and in the next turn a mage set it on fire, nearly wiping the party.[5/5] Immersion What can I say about this one, except it is perfect? The dialouges are interesting and you can have them with literally every person on the map (except the mobs of course...). A certain talent allows you to speak with animals, which often have an intersting story to tell, a funny sentence (Imagine a rooster saying: "Soon the cleaver of decapitation will be turned upon you, the revolution is coming!!"), or even tips on how to solve puzzles.[5/5] MapAll of the levels are beautiful designed and contain many details. There are hidden secrets and treasure, quests off the beaten path. Could you ask for more?[4.5/5] GraphicsThe graphics are held in a isometric view and rotatable by some 90°, but you can zoom in really close and look your hero into the eyes (while having a cool blurred background). The game nicely plays with different ambient lighting and weather effects. The spell effects are solid, not always brilliant, but definitly nice. Some of the animations are kind of clunky, yet they do not destroy the atmosphere or immersion.[4/5] AudioThe game has a amazing soundtrack, that beautifully accompanies combat, travel or dialgoues. All the other audio is solid, but sometimes repetitive.Take for example the marketplace of the first city, where you will spend very much time. All of the merchants have a few lines they say, some funny, some serious. But they repeat that few lines over and over again.After hearing "No one has as many friends, as the man with the many cheeses!" for the 40th time you have an urge to slaughter that man, believe me. Only a few of the dialouges are spoken, but considering the vast amount of dialouges I guess it's ok. Yet, everything that is spoken is done very well.[NA/5] DevelopersI had no contact with the developers.Though it has some flaws this game is definitly worth buying. It is highly addictive, especially in coop. Divinity: Original Sin is one of my favourite games of all time.Final Rating 4.5 out of 5 stars - Fix the bugs and some of the minor flaws and this game is perfection.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												D:OS is a gorgeously polished old-school RPG in the traditions of Baldur's Gate and similar top-down isometric games.   Its story is engaging and deep if one takes the time to slow down and read.Pros:Beautiful graphics and amazing soundtrackCrunchy tactical turn-based combat (reminiscent of Fallout/Fallout2 and XCOM meets digital D&D)Rewarding to play without the help of online guides -- provides a real sense of accomplishment & advancementThoughtful storyline with no "morality meter" -- your choices can affect the plot and open or close certain possibilitiesGood mix of RP-investigation, puzzles, exploration and combatVery little hand-holding: no quest trackers on the radar, easy to get in over your head in combat. Fun and brain-teasing!It's multiplayer co-op!  Go find a duo buddy on your friends list.Cons:Cumbersome inventory systemLots of text to read, if you don't like text (why are you playing old-school RPGs if you don't want to read, tho?)Early game can be difficult until one figures out the character build system.  Plan on re-starting once or twice to find a build you like for your Source HuntersSome combats can be very puzzle-like... this may be a + or - depending on your personal preferences. 9/10 would replay and struggle against the oblivion of the Void again.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												This game is everything I love about video games. It's extremely engaging and a game that is enjoyed best with friends. You will start strategizing, planning out, and manuvering about how to make the best of a situation. You have complete freedom to do whatever it is you want, and your actions actually matter.The writing is as strong as the gameplay. Since the actions you take have real impactful outcomes, you will pay attention to what people are saying, which makes you really focused on the awesome quests there are. This game doesn't dumb anything down. It expects a lot of you. It's challenging, but never impossible. Being able to make the environment a strategic part of a fight feels natural and fun, and you will miss the combat system once you play other RPGs. You will want more, you will want to know what happens to the NPCs, you will want to defeat that boss, you will want to play this game all the time. Enjoy it while it's fresh. Take your time. Personally, it's my GoTY. There's no shame in recreating your characther after a while. I've restarted countless times, and I experience the game differently each time. It's the best game I've played. I wouldn't think twice about reccommending it to anyone who loves strategy and classic-style RPGs. Or anyone.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Though I'm only 18 hours in as of this point, I must say it is the best cRpg I've played... It might not mean much seeing as I've only played baldur's gate 2 and drakensang before this, but this game should set an example to all future RPG games. The interactivity is amazing, if it's not the ground/a building you can interact with it, and in many ways. Even things that would be trivial in other games like crates and barrels, load up your inventory with them, go into combat, and make a maze while you're in combat, or sneaking around and dropping them off while you scurry back a safe distance to initiate.Another thing that stands out is that EVERY stat/talent/ability matters, and you should have each member be varied in what they're expertised in so that you have someone for every situation. Perception lets you spot secrets/traps/switches, and is even needed for discovering things in the main story to continue so it's not just a trivial stat that you can reload every time you step on a trap, Having a character with leadership grants a boost to your whole parties initiative, damage, precision and so forth. Having a loremaster lets you identify items, enemies, and objects... and so on.The crafting system is pretty nice too, generally if you think two items should combine they generally do. For example, a branch + nine inch nails would make a spiked club, though if things don't combine you may need a higher crafting level :P.There's absolutely NO hand holding, past a few tutorial popups which just tell you the basics, When you're initiating a quest, you're expected to read through and actually find this location without any help markers, no ignoring the story you must read some of the finer details. The things I've listed above are only what's on the surface, It's a very deep and detailed game, and compared to modern rpgs, a godsend. I wholly recommend this to anyone who is interested in classic rpgs, and even modern rpg fans (though the difficulty may be a bit much for a casual ;), there is an easy setting... I haven't tried it though, I hear it's much easier than default though.)

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												Overall impression: A good classic style RPG with some new ideas to gameplay. Unfortunately alot of these ideas don't pan out. Note: I played this game solo and in my opinion the game really is best played as a co-op. Aesthetic: The graphics and music are nice even on the medium levels and it runs well. In terms of theme it is a classic kind of fantasy game set within an already established fictional world. So, yes expect dragons, orcs, undead, and all that to be present.Gameplay: The game is tactical and turn based in terms of combat but in a unique action point based system. Also there are no movement grids but moving in combat does cost action points and leaves you open to attacks of opportunity. The games first fault is its unrelenting difficulty even on normal. Now while on hard this game boasts some of the smartest enemy AI I have ever seen, the AI also has a distinct predilection for cheating. Also the game does a very poor job of directing you where to go next. Now in an open world game this would be expected, but this is not an open world game. The games biggest faults are its diplomacy system and its puzzle elements. The puzzle elements are frustrating and completely unnecessary and often involve finding tiny buttons that blend in with the enviroment. The diplomacy system however is the worst offender. It uses a ridiculous rock-paper-scissor system that makes you feel like it is meaningless to put points into upgrading your diplomatic abilities since the computer cheats at it. Plus you can attempt to skip it  by pressing an option button but makes it completely random whether you win or lose the argument. Now I know they put this in for the co-op to settle disputes between the players but in solo it is pointless and annoying and overall just bad game design.Story: The game's strong point is its humor which is very self aware, tongue in cheek, and even breaks the fourth wall a number of times. Its a game that knows its telling a generic fantasy story. That being said the story is very good and has some very dark themes to it. It also becomes serious in tone at the appropriate moments.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												This game is overall great.  Took me a moment to wrap my head around the concept that even though an area is accessible the enemies aren't necessarily beatable yet.  I had to recreate my characters 3 times to get what I felt like was a decent composition, but that was part of the fun since there's so much to choose from.  Of course part of the problem is you're setting a large amount of customization before you even see waht the world has to offer.Sort of like Turn-based Diablo meets Dark Souls meets Baldur's Gate meets Dungeon Siege.Lots of inventory management, lots of different things to customize, lots of challenging battles, lots of interesting combat situations.For instance, if there is poison on the ground you can blow it up with fire, and you can then put oil on the fire to make a black smoke archers cannot see through.  You can make it rain and then chill someone in order to have a chance to freeze them.  You can use the rainwater to strengthen your electricity spells instead, etc etc etc.Worth a shot if you're into the genre.  If you're a super casual player, I'm not sure if I can recommend or not.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												This game has many terrific aspects about it but there is one thing that shines the most - its marvellously executed co-op play. We've been playing the game with my wife for quite some time and we are having a blast. First of all, the ability to create a character, customize both skills and appearance and meaningfully roleplay and interact not only in the game world but also between the characters themselves - well, this is something we don't see often if ever. And then there are moral choices that contribute to your character's personality (which in turn provides usefull bonuses to stats and skills), simple but cleverly constructed way to solve players decision conflicts and thoroughly enjoyable banter between your ingame avatars. Add a vivid world, original mythology, interesting setting and a storyline with enough mysteries and twists to keep you involved - and you have a game that's transcends the boundaries of the genre to become something that I might recommend everyone to try. Moreso if you have a willing friend or that special someone to share your experience with.

Divinity is a great game and the developers put a staggering amount of thought into it. It's been an absolute blast playing it co-op and coordinating to execute tactics and tweak builds. I have no regrets.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Hands down one of the best RPGs in a very long time. The best part: It doesn't take itself very seriously. It's filled with witty occurences and characters, even some of the enemies are hands down ridiculous, which gives the game so much character. The reactivity of the game, the physics of it all is probably one of the more impressive ones I've seen in gaming thus far, how different types of matter reacts with one another, especially how you can strategize that during the turn based combat system is really in my opinion quite mindblowing, and one of the first times I have enjoyed a turn based system of this kind. A definite, and HUGE bonus is that the game doesn't tell you what to do, and in many occurences you actually have to guess that something is actually a quest, even though you will never get a quest log or quest marker for it, you may still at the same time get experience points for completing them. That kind of intuition in a game is something I've long saught after, all the way back to the days of arcanum, baldur's gate and fallout, as gamers we have become bereft of good RPG gaming experiences for a long time now and I am so grateful for this game and how it really brings so much fresh and old material together into the game of the year thus far. It remains to be seen what Wasteland 2 and Pillars of Eternity may achieve, but for the moment this is my favourite game in years, and definitely of this year.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												This game is overall great.  Took me a moment to wrap my head around the concept that even though an area is accessible the enemies aren't necessarily beatable yet.  I had to recreate my characters 3 times to get what I felt like was a decent composition, but that was part of the fun since there's so much to choose from.  Of course part of the problem is you're setting a large amount of customization before you even see waht the world has to offer.Sort of like Turn-based Diablo meets Dark Souls meets Baldur's Gate meets Dungeon Siege.Lots of inventory management, lots of different things to customize, lots of challenging battles, lots of interesting combat situations.For instance, if there is poison on the ground you can blow it up with fire, and you can then put oil on the fire to make a black smoke archers cannot see through.  You can make it rain and then chill someone in order to have a chance to freeze them.  You can use the rainwater to strengthen your electricity spells instead, etc etc etc.Worth a shot if you're into the genre.  If you're a super casual player, I'm not sure if I can recommend or not.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I feel the game's release was rushed so yes the game isn't perfectly polished. Having said that, if you're looking for an immersive RPG experience, one where you truly feel like you're on an adventure, this is the game for you. As a turn based/strategy rpg fan the combat of this game is satisfying. It is like a turn based version of Dragon age original meets magicka. However the game is so much more than just combat. If you're going to play this game I strongly suggest that don't rely on the internet (unless if it's for crafting.) Put yourself in the shoes of these 2 source hunters and try to discover everything on your own and guaranteed you'll have a blast. There isn't a specific way to solve a quest or beat the game, yes some of your actions and choices you've made might not be perfect and you might end up in a difficult situation but such is life. So all in all, amazing game. Not a polished diamond but diamond nontheless. Strongly recommended. (The devs are amazing too they really listen to feedbacks and I have no doubt over the next few months the game will only get een better.)

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Normally I am not one for top-down RPG games however I can honestly say that this is one of the best games that I have ever played. So good in fact, that I have found myself sneaking playtime after work. By far my favorite part of this game is the turn-based combat. I feel that with this style one actually gets to experience the powers and abilities as well as apply them in a strategic manner. This comes in handy especially when taking advantage of environmental effects that can really change the course of a battle. The graphics are very well done and the game looks great for being a beta. The next great thing is the conversations. I love being able to play two different personalities and still advance both. I remember playing NWN and if you had a druid in your party you could not even kill a cow without damaging its alignment much to the anger of druish friends. Every decision you make actually feels like it effects everything else and I love that rush. If you have an RPG itch you need to scratch then this is the title for you. The only issue with the game is that the multiplayer is a bit of a miss with friends only able to play your characters. A simple abilitiy to host a game so each person can play as themself would have been a great idea. However, this fault in no way hurts the true awesomeness of this game.

Early Access Review
								This is a amzing RPG, I Started with a Cleric and Wizard with my 2nd try just because I needed the heals. Playing this game without looking up a walkthough is great fun and is also a fun challange. Having to move objects out the way to find a switch, or not being able to talk to a NPC with a specific character is always fun. You can also be a "♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; To your own starting characters making both of them have verbal fights and arguements with each other.No matter what character you start with you start with the same gear making the game that much more challanging, I belive that this should be changed so that you can have a Idea on how to build your character if you are new to the RPG genre. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I know people have mix feelings with Early Access games, but Divinity: Original Sin is one of the better ones that have had consistent updates, developers listening to feedback from players and making changes/improvements to the game. The jump from Alpha to Beta is pretty damn noticeable and I'm not just talking about the graphics but the core elements of the game itself that have made it even better than it already was thanks due to the feedback from players and developers listening to them. Bugs/glitches have also been fixed. If you have any feedback you like to say after playing the beta do please visit the forums, more than likely they will respond and take note of your feedback.As for the game itself, it's a very ambitious game. A RPG that is Open World with optional On-Line Co-Op and it's Turn Based. When you think about it, there haven't been any WRPG's that have all of that, Shadowrun Returns, X-Com, South Park, Might and Magic X, and Child of Light aren't Open World and are also linear. Most people would turn away after hearing it's Turn Based but it's for the best for this sort of game. If it was action based it would turn into another Diablo clone and there's plenty of them out there already. The combat in Divinity: Original Sin is very deep that let's you play all sorts of styles with your character made Avatars. Weather will also play an element to the combat as it will affect the battles.The game itself doesn't take itself too seriously it can be lighthearted at times but most importantly it has fun with it's missions/side quest. No need to worry of fetch quest in this, Larian the Developer of this game have said they would avoid doing that sort of quests.  :)One other interesting thing to note. The game will come with a RPG Editor that made this game, it will be avaliable around the game release. You'll be able to make mods for this game and put it up to Steamworks. Divinity: Original Sin will be very Mod friendly. Will be interesting to see what type of mods this game will have down the road. Anyways do yourself a favor, if your looking for a great lengthy Open World WRPG game to play, then this game is for you!Oh and one more thing to note, the music in the game is awesome!!!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												A great game, if you like turn based combat, great coop multiplayer and a slow paced game that gives you 40+ hours of content, go and get this game, but be warned, any updates to this game from the publisher (or modding community) are unlikely.A quite complete list of features and scores is available here:Stat System:  8/10☑A classic stat system that allows you to spend points as you like in any combination☐There are no races or racial traits that you chose, everything is available☑Most stats are easy to understand and everything has tooltips☑Respec is available but very rare, so you have to plan ahead☐Spell progression is a bit slow, since you have to buy skills at a random selection at shops in town.☐Some paths have a slow buildup, especially if you lack gold or get a bad selection in town☑Late game you will have about 15-50 spells, depending on your style☑Spells scale with stats and levels, but some will become obsolete☑Certain traits have a huge impact on your playstile like glass cannon or lone wolfItems and crafting: 8/10☑Item progression is good and you always find something new quite fast☑There are rare crafting meterials you can find but also buy in the shop☑You can craft anything without knowing the recipie, but you will find some of them in the game☐Late game crafting makes you literally immune to nearly all elemental damage really braking the game☐Some crafted items were buggy in the release version, but that may be fixedCombat System: 10/10☑Combat is turn based, but not restricted by tiles or anything☑Every ability has a target indicator showing it's area☑Every spell changes the environment in some way or another. Fire, Water, Ice, Poison, Lightning interact in a specific way together and allow for great combos☑If you lack specific spells there are always alternate ways of doing things e.g. barrels with poison or fire etc☑Animations when trying to target your spells slow down your speed, but they prevent too much boredom while waitingQuests: 6/10☑There is no guideline or hand holding involved in the quests, you can solve them in a number off ways that actually make you think and find a solution, not just simple monster slaying☑Riddles and semi minigames, some of which are interesting☑The game has a huge amount of quests and little details that you have to pay attention to☑A semi open world that is divided in large areas so you have to load the game only once and play for a long time without interruption☐Only 4 different party character that have a story and opinion are available, but you can hire henchmen that are randomly generatedRoleplaying: 8/10☑You can play any style you like and still progress in the main story and side quests☑Kill them all or let them live (and come back later to kill them!)☑The main characters have their own personality and don't always agree on things, so you fight in a game of rock-paper-scissors☑You can play your character in any style you like and you are not limited to class choices, only to your stats and traitsBossfights: 4/10☐Bosses are rare and not very impressing, because they use the same spells as you☐Some strategys can be superior against bosses e.g. I defeated the last boss without taking any hit and having him permanently stunnedMultiplayer: 10/10☑2 Player Multiplayer with up to 4 with mods from the stram workshop☑Official game lobbys or private passworded games are possible☑Everyone has their own character(s) and can roam around freely, without the need to listen to dialogues from another player, unless you are close to him☑There is an instant teleportation item to quickly travel to another player or location☑Every character can run on it's own, but you can enable follow modeMods: 3/10☑There is official modding support and tools☐Steam workshop has only a few good mods and no active communityTotal Score: 57/80Who cares about that score anyways?

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I feel the game's release was rushed so yes the game isn't perfectly polished. Having said that, if you're looking for an immersive RPG experience, one where you truly feel like you're on an adventure, this is the game for you. As a turn based/strategy rpg fan the combat of this game is satisfying. It is like a turn based version of Dragon age original meets magicka. However the game is so much more than just combat. If you're going to play this game I strongly suggest that don't rely on the internet (unless if it's for crafting.) Put yourself in the shoes of these 2 source hunters and try to discover everything on your own and guaranteed you'll have a blast. There isn't a specific way to solve a quest or beat the game, yes some of your actions and choices you've made might not be perfect and you might end up in a difficult situation but such is life. So all in all, amazing game. Not a polished diamond but diamond nontheless. Strongly recommended. (The devs are amazing too they really listen to feedbacks and I have no doubt over the next few months the game will only get een better.)

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												If you are even remotely a RPG fan (especially Baldur's Gate / Torment) then you will most likely enjoy this game. This is what Dragon Age should have been, but never was.Divinity: Original Sin also has a few extra things, rarely seen in RPG games:Spells + science = fun + tacticsThrow down oil and burn it or make it rain and freeze the enemies or burn the water for a smoke screen. The possibilities are endless.Item interactionAlmost all items can be interacted with, which includes destroying them. Drop down a barrel of oil and have a fire work party. Or block the road for the enemies.Path findingWhen I move my characters from A to B and there is a dangerous zone in the middle (fire, poison, etc), the characters are smart enough to avoid those zones. Thank God they have half a brain. The "down side" is, so does the enemy.Role playIt's kinda silly when playing single player, but you can go into a discussing with yourself (well, the other character you control). It's still a nice touch and can be fun in co-op.Co-opIt works, 'nuff said.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												A great game, if you like turn based combat, great coop multiplayer and a slow paced game that gives you 40+ hours of content, go and get this game, but be warned, any updates to this game from the publisher (or modding community) are unlikely.A quite complete list of features and scores is available here:Stat System:  8/10☑A classic stat system that allows you to spend points as you like in any combination☐There are no races or racial traits that you chose, everything is available☑Most stats are easy to understand and everything has tooltips☑Respec is available but very rare, so you have to plan ahead☐Spell progression is a bit slow, since you have to buy skills at a random selection at shops in town.☐Some paths have a slow buildup, especially if you lack gold or get a bad selection in town☑Late game you will have about 15-50 spells, depending on your style☑Spells scale with stats and levels, but some will become obsolete☑Certain traits have a huge impact on your playstile like glass cannon or lone wolfItems and crafting: 8/10☑Item progression is good and you always find something new quite fast☑There are rare crafting meterials you can find but also buy in the shop☑You can craft anything without knowing the recipie, but you will find some of them in the game☐Late game crafting makes you literally immune to nearly all elemental damage really braking the game☐Some crafted items were buggy in the release version, but that may be fixedCombat System: 10/10☑Combat is turn based, but not restricted by tiles or anything☑Every ability has a target indicator showing it's area☑Every spell changes the environment in some way or another. Fire, Water, Ice, Poison, Lightning interact in a specific way together and allow for great combos☑If you lack specific spells there are always alternate ways of doing things e.g. barrels with poison or fire etc☑Animations when trying to target your spells slow down your speed, but they prevent too much boredom while waitingQuests: 6/10☑There is no guideline or hand holding involved in the quests, you can solve them in a number off ways that actually make you think and find a solution, not just simple monster slaying☑Riddles and semi minigames, some of which are interesting☑The game has a huge amount of quests and little details that you have to pay attention to☑A semi open world that is divided in large areas so you have to load the game only once and play for a long time without interruption☐Only 4 different party character that have a story and opinion are available, but you can hire henchmen that are randomly generatedRoleplaying: 8/10☑You can play any style you like and still progress in the main story and side quests☑Kill them all or let them live (and come back later to kill them!)☑The main characters have their own personality and don't always agree on things, so you fight in a game of rock-paper-scissors☑You can play your character in any style you like and you are not limited to class choices, only to your stats and traitsBossfights: 4/10☐Bosses are rare and not very impressing, because they use the same spells as you☐Some strategys can be superior against bosses e.g. I defeated the last boss without taking any hit and having him permanently stunnedMultiplayer: 10/10☑2 Player Multiplayer with up to 4 with mods from the stram workshop☑Official game lobbys or private passworded games are possible☑Everyone has their own character(s) and can roam around freely, without the need to listen to dialogues from another player, unless you are close to him☑There is an instant teleportation item to quickly travel to another player or location☑Every character can run on it's own, but you can enable follow modeMods: 3/10☑There is official modding support and tools☐Steam workshop has only a few good mods and no active communityTotal Score: 57/80Who cares about that score anyways?
