content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												You know those games where it feels like the devs took time to make sure even the little aspects of the games had significant time spent on them? This is one of those games.One common flaw in turn based tactical games is the combat is just not tactical enough. D:OS does an amazing job with their skill system combined with the environmental dangers on the battlefield. I found I wasn't doing well until I was utilizing the environment in almost every battle, and it is awesome.Co-op games are so easy to set up! I had 0 issues getting my friend in my game and its fast every game. If I had one issue with the game it comes in this category though. Conversations started by one person are difficult and sometimes not observable by the other player. I want to see that amazing story too!Are there bugs? Yes, but nothing gamebreaking and not many considering it just released. The one bug I kept encountering they fixed in one of their 4 small patches in 4 days anyways. I love knowing the devs won't wait forever to patch this game.

Mods can be loaded, so that's an infinite supply of adventures. Haven't looked too much into that yet, but appears similar to the NWN community from my day.All in all, a magnificent game. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												My personal honest review of this game as an avid RPG player. Never played the early access version of the game.Initially created a female witch and a male knight. 60 hours later I ended up with a female pyro-ranger and a male elemental scoundrel. Character class? There’s none. And that’s a beauty. (Character development – 12/10)Classic turn-based combat system with a unique touch - elements and environmental objects to manipulate. Managed to take out groups of mobs without even engaging a fight, many times. Gotta love dem oil barrels and candles! (Battle system – 12/10)Helped a poetic-romantic sailor tom cat hook up with his materialistic soulmate by snatching a collar after killing a bigass monster that kills dragons. The cats are now married and live happily in the tavern. (Story and quests – 12/10)Everything is soooo purrrttyyy…., but camera can be a bit drunk at times. (Graphics – 9/10)Paid a bunch of coins to a lady for some good time – and she read me a story instead of making out. Got blown to bits and pieces with a sheep nearby due to my excessive passion of grave-digging.  Stole some smelly personal belongings for Murphy, the dog with Scooby’s voice. (Humor, traps and NPC variety – 12/10)Found myself humming the game’s intro theme all day long instead of the usual Disney’s Frozen’s “Let It Go”. As a father of one little girl, trust me this is big. (Music – 10/10)Spent more than 60 hours playing this game, and just got my party to the second town (not even halfway through the game based on my achievements). This game is MASSIVE. Additionally, you can stack barrels, cook food, craft weapons and armors, stack boxes, brew potions, write spells, enchant stuff, hack doors, and more. (Fun and replayability – 12/10)This game made me wrote my very first good and honest game review. No, I don’t usually do reviews. English’s not even my 1st language. So yeah, I’m pretty damn impressed with this game. No go buy this game and start stacking things! (OVERALL – 11/10).

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												This is probably one of the best traditional RPG that I've played since Baldur's Gate 2.  The story is a little bit lacking, and the mechnic of developing a relatonship between your two PCs was a good idea but implemented poorly (you shouldn't link role playing mechanics with gameplay mechanics).  There are a good variety of quests, and the very first major quest you embark on is a interesting and fun murder mystery investigation.  The later quests aren't quite as extensive or well executed, but there are enough variety to stop things from being dull.The combat is the highlight.  It's good ol' fashioned turn-based combat, and the interaction between the various elements and the environmental effect mechanics make every battle its own fun little puzzle.  Do I blow up the poison gas barrels and create a cloud of poison that enemies won't pass through to protect my flank?  Do I use fire to blow up the gas for a bit of extra damage?  Do I want to freeze that puddle of water so enemies will slip, or do I shoot a bolt of lightning at it to stun everyone standing in the puddle?If you are a fan of RPGs there is literally no reason not to get this game.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Long have I searched for an RPG that captures the nostalgic feelings of Baldur's Gate that innovates and improves with modern technology and game design. My search has ended.Divinity: Original Sin provides a compelling atmosphere with a lengthy list of party customization that allows you to build an effective party based on your own, personal whims. Want a caster who can also get up in to melee range and go to town? Done. Want a ranger that casts spells alongside her arrows? Done. All you need to do is learn some of the basics and figure out what abilities will complement one another and you're good to go.On that note: This game is not (typically) easy. Be prepared to save and load games frequently! The tides of battle can and often are easily decided on your tactical decisions, and sometimes incapacitating an enemy at a crucial moment really does mean all the difference.The game also allows you to build two very different characters in terms of personality. Your characters can have conversations with one another and your choices during these conversations will help shape how that character is at their core. If all that wasn't enough to interest you, then I'd suggest looking to the company themselves. They have a very clear understanding about what makes this kind of game enjoyable, and their commitment to go from KickStarter to launch proves they are willing to support this project going forward.TL;DR: If you enjoy tactical based RPG games such as old school Baldur's Gate then you'll probably really enjoy Divinity: Original Sin. If you want a game you can just blast through without much thought, you may be disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												This game requires a little bit of patience.  There will be no hand holding, no quest markers, no arrow pointing you where to go.  You have to explore carefully and thoroughly to make progress.  The beginning in particular will have you poking around town for a good hour or two before you get out to kill undead.  That being said, what a fantastic game.  Remindes me a lot of the old DnD games like Baldur's Gate and Temple of Elemental Evil except you don't need to have the DnD players manual memorized to make reasonable characters :P  The story is an engaging mystery with well paced discovery.  Even the side quests fit well, they never feel repetative or grindy.  You don't walk into towns and just click on every SoB with an exclamation mark over his head, no no.  You actually have to talk to everyone, find out who needs things done, then figure out how to do it.  It's usually much more vague then "bring me 10 bear paws" and many have more then one way to get the job done.  I've never really liked crafting in these games, though the systems here seem fairly robust.  The UI isn't perfect, combining items that exist on different pages of your inventory can require a few clicks, but the combines all seem to have a very natual feel to it that makes sense.The combat system is fantastic.  The action point system and they way unused action points carry over to the next turn is really good and not something I've seen before.  No one has mana or energy bars, everything boils down to action points and cooldowns.  Normally I dislike playing wizards in RPG's since they tend to just nuke however this game has some great options for support wizards.  I have a wizard with something like 15 spells and only one is a nuke.  Lots of interesting mechanics you don't see in other games, I won't go into too much detail, but as an example, I never thought rain would be such a useful spell.  RAIN?  What other game do you think, hmmm.... I think I should cast rain, in the middle of a fight?The multiplayer seems pretty slick too, for playing with friends.  I imagine playing with random people would be frustrating as all hell, but great for playing with people you know.Best fantasy RPG since Dragon Age: Origins in my opinion.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												It's a fantastic game, and if you've played e.g Divine Divinity you know what to expect. A fantastical RPG game which doesn't take itself very seriously.It has all the necessary trappings, character development, quests, magic, monsters and lots of mayhem. Like the previous games it also has a lot of things you are free to break, and lots of ways to do it. A guard bothering you? Teleport him out of the way. A big baddie too tough? Bring him back to town and let the guards take care of him.As for new things, the way you develop your characters is well done and a new take on the old formula, but it works rather well. The magic system is ingenious and fun to play around with. The dual characters and the role playing happening between them is a welcome break from the rest of the game.All that needs to be said though is buy it! Buy it and make your friends buy it so you can teleport them into lava and laugh at their misfortune.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Okay, first off I'll try to write this review in assumption that half of you reading have played games like this (Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights) while the other half aren't really familiar with the DnD playstyle.The Good:1) Visually satisfying. The environment, character modles, and partical effects of spells are stunning. I could try to describe it with and do it little justice. So just look at some screenshots and some gameplay videos. I'll try to reveal things about the game that you don't usually get from watching other people play.2) Soundtrack is quite stellar as well, again though i won't do it much justice by describing it, just watch someone stream it on Twitch.tv3) Lore/Story. I wont give anything away about the actual story, so I'll just describe how the game handles quest and such. It's a non-linear style questing system, so you can just go about your business and do whatever you want. There is a main questline in which you can progress through the main/side quests without going through a set series of NPCs to talk to. You need to find a missing NPC? You dont need to have the quest before hand. Exampl: NPC needs you to find a missing item. You can stumble upon it and retrieve it without having the quest and when the NPC requests you to find the item, you can present it to them. That goes with almost all other kinds of quests. 4) Crafting. Quite fun. The crafting is like MInecraft's system in a sense that you can make anything just know YOU (the player) personally know the what do combine. The only contributes in which crafting skills add is to unlock higher tiered items to make and crafting time (from what I've noticed). There are books in-game that have a fun (fun for me) description on how to craft stuff. A crafitng book may have a flavor like. . . "I'm no lumberjack, but anytime I come across a log, I take my trusty axe to get some. I'll whittle it away with a knife to make a couple of stakes, and those blasted wizards always want some of the leftover woodchips for some reason." So that recipe pretty much tells you to get logs from in-game environmental logs on the ground. Combine a knife and a log to make a stake and woodchips. Other examples of how to craft is by combining Flour and Water to make Dough. Combine a hammer to a tomato to make tomato sauce. Combine the sauce and dough to make pizza dough. Toss that into an oven to make a pizza!Oh, and this made me EXCEEDLING happy when I found out that you can combine a Fly Agaric Mushroom and an Empty Flask to make a Poison Potion. THEN! you can combine it with a weapon, and your weapon will have a permanent Poison x-y damage. I'm still trying out some of the other crafting stuff, so there's still a lot to find out.5) Combat. The nitty gritty of the game. It's turned base combat. The order in turns is determined by how much Intiative you have and it is affected by your Speed attribute; there are a total of 5 attribute stats: Strengh, Dexterity, Constitution, Speed, Perception. EVERYTHING in combat is dicated by Action Points (AP), there is no mana to cast spells; they all run on AP and cooldown timers (in turns, ie: 3 turn cooldown). You want to walk over to that zombie and start unloading on him? You need to spend AP to move there AND then spend more AP to swing your weapon. Movement dictates how many meters you can walk in 1 AP. Movement is affected by type of armor (heavier gives you a movement penalty, but can be reduced or removed with ability points), and the Speed attribute also dictates your movement. Various attribute stats also affect your Maximum AP, Starting AP, and Per Turn AP. Maximum Ap is pretty self-explanitory. Your starting AP determines how much of your max AP you have at the very beginning of the battle. Your Per Turn AP helps you gain more AP per turn. You may also save or roll-over unused AP to unleash on a monster that you just tripped (tripped/stunned monsters have a 100% to be hit). Different types of weapons inherintly use more or less AP. Daggers use 2, one-handed Axes/Swords/Maces use 3. Two-handed weapons use 4(two-handed axes/swords/staves). Bows use 4, and Crossbows use 6. I believe.Okay, phew. Now that AP is taken cared of. Actual combat is quite challenging. It is imperative when battle is initiated that you analyze the battlefield, since all encounters have been hand-placed by the devs, each of the have different playstyle flavors. Some encounters will be better utilized if you have a wizard throw a fireball at barrels of oil to it will light up and burn them all. Or some encounters may favor a sneaky rogue backstabbing (backstabs have a 100% to crit) those mages in the back before your party rushes in. Analyzing the battlefield is so important, not just because of the combination of the monsters and their positions but environmental factors also play a huge role. Elemental Synergy has been worked in this game beautifully. You see enemies standing in a puddle of water? Throw a lightening bolt in it and it will stun anyone in the puddle. Don't have a lightening skill? Throw a fireball or have a ranger shoot a fire arrow in the water to turn it into vapor-- which will obscure vision from those pesky archers *Beware, though, your vision is also hindered behind the vapor* One of the available abilities in the game is Loremaster, which also allows you to identify magical items to see their properties. It also allows you to view the stats of the enemies whening holding down CTRL. With higher levels of Loremaster you'll be able to see the enemies Hp/Max HP, AP/Max AP, Resistances, Armor. Also if you like lore or you just like to be immersed in your games and read a lot/everything you can stumble upon useful information like, this archeologists tells you that skeletons are more resistant to piercing damage but if you have a mace or any crushing damage, their bones will turn to dust. Later on, you can find out through other spells that skeletons have a 75% resistance to piercing damage and take extra damage from crushing.6) Co-op. I had generally wanted to list this in "The Bad" section only because the game limits you to two players, but there are available mods to make it into 4. I personally exptec it to be a 4 player game because its predecessor (Baldur's Gate & Neverwinter Nights) had 4 players, odd decision to go to a 2 player cap. ALTHOUGH, how many people really have 4 friends to really dive into the lore and play for hours and hours and only be level 2 or 3. So there's the counter-argument. Otherwise, the co-op is superb. The host saves and loads but there are also drop-in and drop-out public gameplay. One of the features in this game allows the two main characters (both single and co-op) to both react to environmental factors or decisions. Early on, you find Ishmashell and you have two opposing options. One essentially good, the other evil. If both of you decide two different options there will be a rock-paper-scissors minigame. You need to score 10 points to win and have your way. If you have charm/intimidate/reason points then every win you get awards you the respective points. Someone with 4 intimidate battles someone with 2 reason, the person with 4 intimidate only needs to win 3 games; whereas, the latter person needs to win 5 games. This applies to trying to intimidate/reason/charm NPCs.I will post 'The Bad' section on another post. I am running out of room.

												First off, if you like classic RPGs pick this game up right off the bat.This game is beautifully designed with a great atmosphere and stunning visuals coupled with one heck of a soundtrack to boot.Combat is fluid and satisfying once you get a couple of the more advanced spells.Spells can combo off each other into a spectacular explosion or a poison cloud or a ... you get the point.And with two players it gets even better, if you don't kill each other first that is.The dialogue often throws choices at the player(s) so you get to debate with your friend... in a game of rock, paper, scissors.Should we kill those people? content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Me and my buddy were roleplaying some coop. We were investigating a murder which led us to the graveyard. After spontaneously digging up some graves looking for loot, we stumbled upon a secret cavern. We entered the cavern with big round eyes searching for hidden treasure. The cavern was a large hallway which led to an open cavern with a flowing stream. Standing between us and the winding stream was a hunchback. I approached boldy and shouted my salutations. Within a few feet of the figure, he burst into flames. He then looked up at me, his skeletal grin and empty sockets mocking me. Surprised i stumbled backwards. My partner shouted something incoherent and cast teleportation on the skeleton freak. The freak appeared several yards away near the top of the cavern before falling unceremoniously back to the ground. By the time he hit the ground i was already invisible. I creeped over to him as he stood back up. I then noticed a large flaming mechanism in his hand. I ignored this and slipped behind him. I then slid my daggers into his fiery back with a shout of fury. The skeletons head twisted completely around and grinned at me. I let out a shriek as my daggers melted and fire spread up my arms. The fire spread to my torso before i felt the heat. I couldn't help myelf, i screamed bloody murder as i ran in the opposite direction of the stream. I made it nearly a dozen feet before i crumpled to the ground and groaned as i felt my penultimate sigh leave my body as a small puff of steam. My partner screamed in agony as she saw me die. In a manner of rage she charged forward and cast spells at the fiery figure. She took a step out into the clearing and her eyes widened as several skeleton hands forced themselves out of the earth. Soon followed by the bodies of the undead. She stood surrounded by these grinning figures as the fiery figure slowly stalked closer to her. In a rage unrivaled by heroes of old she swung daggers and slung spells untill all were bonepiles except for the fiery abomination. Still grinning, it lifted the mechanism and pointed it at her. A fiery stream protruded from it and she was momentarily engulfed, using her quick wit she throws herself to the ground and rolls. As she stands back up with scraps of burnt clothing remaining, she notices she dropped her pack. From it protrudes a scroll. "The resurection scroll we knicked from the wizard!" She leaps forward and grabs it, still lying on the ground as she recites the incantation. She is already on her feet by the time I am lifted off the ground by some invisible force. My burns diseappear and i land on my feet running toward the flaming skeleton. He aims his mechanism and i slide across the ground underneath him as the flames shoot above me. At the same time my partner is knocking a water arrow and shoots it. It strikes the skeleton in the face, water engulfing it. Steam rises as i do, and i plunge what is left of my daggers into its back. I twist the handles and pull out rapidly, the skeleton lets out a cry and explodes in an inferno. I am disintegrated instantly and my partner's skin melts from the extreme heat. As she slumps to her knees, she hears a faint sound from the stream. The water is gurgling, but it almost sounds like a laugh. She lands on her side and wonders if things would have been different if she had only married the fishmonger her mother was so keen on. Oh, why did she have to live a life of adventure? 11/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This is CRPG done right: non-linear questing, meaningful character development, deep turn based tactical combat, a consistently interactive world, cool loot, crafting, lore, humour, etc. I cannot thank the developers enough for the commitment they had to bringing a quality modern-day successor to old-school crpgs. The game literally feels like it combined the best and most complex systems of older rpgs, and then upgraded them while adding a few original twists to them. It has the tactical combat of something like the temple of elemental evil (perhaps a bit more streamlined, but superior in depth and challenge), the interactive world of something like fallout 1 or 2 (but again, with much better implemented and more varied systems), the lore and scope of the likes of baldur's gate 2, and more than a few new ideas of its own to keep things interesting. And most importantly, everything ties in well together to form a coherent, consistent sand box of rpg experimentation. Be warned however! This game requires an insane commitment of time and attention. There are so many things to micromanage. But that is exactly what I love about it. It is not a simple matter of grinding until your numbers are high enough. It rewards patience, exploration, experimentation and careful decision making. It is entirely possible to screw yourself over completely in this game... which again, makes for an awesome role playing experience. Progress does not come swiftly or at a steady pace. There may long stretches of time when you are just trying to figure out the best way to outfit your characters. You might spend an hour navigating a house full of traps and figuring out how to get all of the loot without blowing yourself up. You might spend some time learning recipes and crafting items. You might be reloading the same battle 5-10 times. There are literally endless possibilities of both emergent and prescripted gameplay...I can only hope that Larian studios, as well as other developers, get the message and start making more games like these.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												This is my first review on Steam, although I have written reviews on other services, but given that I will merely enumerate a few high-level points given there are probably a hundred better reviews already.1) Combat is difficult on Normal, but with some thought and experience you can win, and win in style.  Be patient, save right before each fight so that you can reload if you make a tactical mistake.  Winning a battle in D:OS gives you a real sense of satisfaction.2) Gold is difficult to come by early on if you do not steal.  I am not a thief therefore I had to scrimp and save to obtain gold early on.  That extra scroll, potion, armor, etc. can be key in the combat so make that early gold count.3) I tend to be thrifty with single-use items like scrolls, health potions, etc. but again, to win a close battle and not lose any of your team members you may need to sacrifice going for damage and burn action points to quaff that potion.The game is very in-depth, a good challenge, with nice graphics, humorous moments, and a nice mix of quests (I am only up to the Silverglen area so I cannot speak to the entirety of the game at this time.)  The game world is large, and is an "open world" but the level of the enemies encountered make it linear to a degree in reality as you simply will not survive the fights if you veer too far off the path.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												You can explore dungeons, wilderness, urban, fight monsters & NPCS (turn-based,) roleplay with PCs/NPCs, and solve traps, tricks, & puzzles. You participate in a "story" through quests in this fantasy RPG world. What makes this game unique-- Compelling array of magical spells that can be cast tactically during combat so as to combine with each other, and create effects and injure opoonents. For example, casting an oil slick to slow an target, then igniting it and the target with a fire spell. Alternatively, chilling an opponent and then freezing it. The possiblities are large. An engaging wilderness environment. Combat that is amazingly balanced, almost perfectly to the character levels. Combat that is intense, interesting, and challenging. Beautiful graphics. A reward systems of skills, talents, etc that allow you to customise the character uniquely. A well-paced game that is neither dull nor hugely exciting but then you suffer a large period of boredom -- no, the game is consistently paced.This game can be addictive it is that good.Each of these good points may not seem special, but when you combineall of them together you get Divinity Original Sin (I know it sounds corny but it's true).This is one of the greatest games of the last 15 years. Of course, benefits continue: you have multi-player; you can select a certain "class" but ultimately create whatever you want, literally anything, within the bounds of traits, talents, ability scores, etc; which gives you huge scope to customise characters from the start and throughout the game. You create and control more than one character at a time.Buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin is a throwback to what Action RPGs used to be.  When I was a young adult back in the late 90s early 2000s we had games like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape Torment, and Nox.  These games, while real-time based (technically based on DND rules), flowed well and the envrionment was at your disposal.  Divinity should not be compared to any of these games as the gameplay itself may be similar but some of the major elements are still missing.  Divinity is a turn based action RPG based in the Divinity world.  You don't need any former knowledge of the series but you will see some appearances and references to other games.  The world is, in my opinion, a medium sized world that captures your attention and makes it feel much larger due to several factors.  First, everything is usable or can be modified from one state to another.  Some of this comes into play during combat.  In fact, some battles that could not normally be won until a later level can be won earlier if you play your battle correctly.  Oil barrels that explode upon getting hit by a fireball, poison barrels that lay poison onto the ground which can be ignited by fire, and water that can be electrically charged, stunning everything in its area.  These are all aspects of a battle that can be turned against you or the enemy, don't forget, blood conducts electric too, so that blood puddle isn't something you want to stand in if a mage is slamming bolts everywhere!The one thing that really intrigues me as well as adds points to the game is the difficulty.  This game, as said before, is a throwback to the old school games of the early part of last decade.  There are no quest markers or hand holding.  You need to figure things out for yourself and this could be a turn off to the new generation of gamers.  Please don't take this as an insult but most newer games step you through the entire game, Divinity does no such thing.  The map is useful for markers that you can place, town areas of interest, secret boxes marked on your map, and waypoints.  With no handholding you are left to fend for yourself, this often entails you wandering for a few minutes until you get your bearings.  Walls of text that can get in the way and have no meaning to the current quest line can get annoying but are there to help you immerse yourself.  Quests can often go either way, kill the troll or let him live.  Sometimes you find friends in the strangest areas, so before you go blasting into combat make sure that the skeleton you get your eyes on isn't a friendly.That brings me to the combat which is extremely well designed.  Everything is turn based meaning that each character goes and does what he/she does for their turn and then it is the next characters turn, friend or foe.  Action points make up your characters ability set and define how many things they can do in a given turn.  Walking, attacking, casting most spells, and drinking potions all consume action points.  The good news is, if you want, you can save up your action points to a certain amount and unload three, four, or even five attacks in one turn.  This adds an element to the combat that makes it strategic.  Some spells cost so much that you need to wait one turn to even cast them while other spells have a cooldown regardless of how many action points you have stored up.  As you level your characters you quickly learn how to lose professionally.  Enemies two levels above you can completely pulverize your party unless you got a trick up your sleeve.  However, the level difference begins to get a little easier as you get more powerful.  Character creation is somewhat of a detailed job that you can easily spend an hour getting right.  The classes presented to you are merely templates as you can modify them to be anything.  Want a geomancer with pyromancing abilities? Go for it.  Want a mage that can wear heavy armor and cast spells?  Sure, go for it.  You do end up sacrificing some things over others as going the latter route will undoubtly have you suffering in one aspect or the other eventually but it is still a viable jack of all trades class.  I am a personal fan of the Red Mage play style so when I can get a party to have a red mage I do it.  On a final note on character creation, you have to create two as the story line does entail two protagonists, so your other two party members will be whomever you choose as you go throughout the game.As far as the graphics go, the game is good enough.  Nothing stellar but it was never designed in that fashion.  The music rocks and the voice overs are nice.  The game can run on high end systems with no issues and even on middle and low end systems fluidly.Now with every review comes a few of the bad things.  First I would like to point out that you need to read the manual.  This isn't a flaw or a bad thing for me but again, the newer generation wants everything done for them as games are designed in this fashion.  Another flaw is that sometimes you intend to attack an enemy via melee but your character moves around them instead.  I have had this happen a few times and it gets irritating to say the least.  I haven't lost a battle because of this but it drags out some battles an extra turn when it could have been over earlier.  My other complain is the walls of text I referred to earlier.  Sometimes you end up reading a page out of a book from one conversation before the point is made.  While this adds depth, doing this to often gets tiresome, especially when you are eager to go out and whoop some butt.  Overall, Divinity: Original Sin does the old days justice.  It captures what made games so good back then and then amplifies it to another level.  I was really hoping for an open world in which I could go anywhere and do anything.  While you can do as you wish, some areas are just way to powerful for you and you get spanked.  The story has a set path that you will be at certain points at certain levels, give or take one or two.  I don't think this is bad but enemies don't respawn so other than retracing steps to get some older quest complete or a secret dug up, there is little reason to go back to old areas of the map already explored.Points Breakdown:Combat and Controls:9/10* The moving instead of attacking bug/glitch gets annoying so I took a point away here.Graphics:7/10* Nothing Stellar but still good none the less.Sound:9/10*Fantastic Sound track and decent voice acting.Difficulty:9/10*Set it to easy, normal, or hard.  No hand holding!Story:9/10*Well designed from the start.  You begin not knowing much other than that you are a source hunter.

I probably could have finished it earlier if I hadn't become so engrossed in the crafting and loot management - I'm totally a RPG hoarder! number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												While I have only played 13 hours of Divinity: Original Sin, I have played enough to tell you that you need to play it. Why, you ask? Because games are not made like this anymore.  Divinity: Original Sin harkens back to the great CRPGs of the 1990s in style, writing, and gameplay mechanics. The game plays like Baldur's Gate had a sultry affair with Ultima VII and produced a glorious hammer wielding child. Here's a checklist:- Very well written dialogue with laugh out loud humor and wit? Check!- Turn based, tactical combat with real depth and strategy? Check!- No god damned hand-holding every step of the way, treating you like a baby? Check!- INTERESTING quests that make you actually use your brain to figure out how to progress? Check!- Lovingly crafted artwork and graphics that work very well with the setting? Check!- Up to 4 characters in your party? Check!- Ability to role play diaglogue between people in your party, which includes having arguments that affect stats on your character? (Think paragon/renegade stuff from Mass Effect, except in this game it actually increases/decreases an array of stats) Check!- Crafting that is incredibly practical; need a spear? Grab a stick and a dagger or knife and voila! Check!The game is as close to a pen and paper RPG as I've ever played. I could go on for days about this game, but you have to try it. Give Larian $40, they surely deserve it. Again, I've only played 13 hours, but they have been incredily engrossing and enjoyable. I cannot wait to continue delving deeper into this game!

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Though I've only played through the first area, I've spent hours upon hours just exploring the wonderful land Larian Studios has developed. The mechanics are fantastic, the elements of the classic RPG are there, and the combat is visceral. The story is a classic RPG/DnD story set in a fantasy/medieval setting. It definitely is relatable to the classic games such as the original Fallouts and Baldur's Gate. While the combat is turn based, I don't think I've had my interest wavered due to the extraordinary combinations of moves you can do. The environment is interactable where you can electricute the water an enemy is standing in to stun them - or light poison clouds to produce a mini-explosion. Divinity Original Sin is one of the best RPGs I've played and I heartily recommend it for those wanting to play an in-depth RPG that is related to its older predecessors. This game isn't for the faint of heart though - the game has no hand holding. You have to read your diary and figure out what to do based on your own instincts. All-in-all Divinity Original Sin is a fantastic game worth looking at if you're wanting an extremely cool RPG to play.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												VERY good conecept, however it fails to deliver on many fronts. The combat is fairly buggy and there are some things that aren't explained. Also I feel like many playstyles are inherently worse than othersCombat: Targeting AoE often claims you won't hit a unit, yet when you use the ability it does hit said unit. Annoying when you hit your own guys when you shouldn't. Also you can abuse the system and kill units without entering combat by using burning oil to hit enemies outside of engage range. Things that are not explained: The biggest one of these are that when you have to progress near the end you need to not only have all the star stones, you have to been to the homestead once for each stone you unlock, this took me roughly eight hours to figure out since I assumed I'd missed a star stone.All in all it has many flaws, but it's still a fantastic game that I'd definitely recommend. Less replay value than I first hoped though.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Good RPG for about 60-80 hours, especially since market lacks good team-based RPGs with turn, tactical combat. Humor and very well made world interaction are additional pros.Game suffer a bit from losing momentum after 2/3 and "nerfing spree" of devs - since small group of people on official forums constantly demands nerfs of various elements, skills, traits and mechanics (because they find game too easy, even on highest difficulty - I found it quite okay and fitting, nothing too hard and nothing "clearing itself"), devs are mostly focused on that aspect, apparently forgetting about additional companions and other features they promised. I finished game before that happened, but if you would run into heavy reduced resistances or find something like "glass cannon" reducing hp by 80% instead of 50%, while giving +2 AP instead of 2x AP per turn, then you will know who to thank for that.But since I cleared the game withing ~75 hours and I dont regret playing, I dare to say that it is still good product. After all, games should be all about fun, right?

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												The art assets are pretty sharp and colorful. The dialogue is good and the choices are interesting. Though a lot of the text it isn't voiced, the game still has great voice work. There are still quite a lot of bugs in this game: Some quests cannot be finished if you try to finish them in a certain way.Sometimes the designers didn't forsee you trying to solve a quest in a specific way, making the dialogue between the questgiver and player incorrect.Sometimes savedgames can get corrupted (this can however be attributed to certain mods screwing things up) so save regularly.The game can crash to desktop at times (also can be attributed to mods).All in all it's a great game and although I'd recommend playing this game on your own pace, I'd still say it is an amazing game to play with friends! A good mod choice for this game would be Fourplay, so you can have up to 4 people playing together rather than only 2.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												This game captures the spirit of Baldurs Gate perfectly!I even would go so far and say it is better. Graphics are really good and it runs flawless on my machine. The music is not superepic but fits in nicely in all the areas.Although there is almost no voice-acting the dialogues are well written and there is plenty to explore if you are interested in the lore!Where the game REALLY shines is the tactical combat. It starts out very good and gets better and better and better.At level 10 you have so many spells and skills and every single one is usable either with the enviorment or works as a catalyst with other spells - this is the best tactical combat I have EVER experienced!I don't know how huge D:OS is. The world just invites me to explore (no quest markers, no quest compass - you have to THINK!) and I cannot remember the last time a game has hooked me in that level. After 22 hours I finished everything around the first village - and that is when the story begins!The quests have a wide reach from funny to creative to combat to explore.And the best thing : If you think of a creative way to solve quests or riddle-situations (there are a lot!) - it usually works!I did not experience a single situation in which I thought "damn, this HAD to work now, but it didn't!"And it gets better and better : This game is actually playable in coop from start to finish! Hell, it is MEANT to be played cooperatively!In addition to the 2 main characters you can recruit 2 more heros. The downside is that these are not customizeable but there are so many options to choose from that it does not really matter, because you can branch them out any way you like anyway.There are no classes in this game, so feel free to experiment. I would even recommend to do so. For example one of my characters started out as a healer and is now a 2hand-tank-cleric-witch and extremely powerfull! This game rewards you to play a hybrid, not like other games! Even with just 1 point in witchcraft (for example) you can use a high-lvl witchcraft spell, but have to pay more action-points to use it in combat. This is just an awesome system!Every npc you meet - and sometimes enemies as well - want to trade stuff with you!If you have a rogue in your party (which I also recommend!) you will spend hours and hours to steal all the good stuff from the nice people in the towns ^^ But beware - if you get cought, you will have to fight. I would recommend loading a quicksave if that happens.Oh, and have you ever been angry about doors in other games? Or chests that you do not have a key for?In D:OS everything works as it logically should : burn down a door with mighty fire-spells, break a chest with your sword or even put a chest in your inventory for later, if you hope to find a key! That is just PURE AWESOMENESS!You can even teleport things like barrels and crates around! Block enemys with them, put an oil-barrel from your inventory next to a boss, ignite the oil and then cast a rain-spell to transform the burning field into a steamcloud followed by a lightning strike that will stun all the wet enemies at once! But beware - such a reaction can hit your party too, with your OWN spells! So always pay attention to positioning!I could go on and on and on, this game had me hooked from the start and I did not have it in my "interesting game"-list.Check it out, play it, you won't regret it! This is VERY VERY hard competition for pillars of eternity, wasteland 2 and torment 2.I will close my review now - this is the 4th night in which I stayed up untill 6am, because the game is so great!GET-IT-NOW!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This is CRPG done right: non-linear questing, meaningful character development, deep turn based tactical combat, a consistently interactive world, cool loot, crafting, lore, humour, etc. I cannot thank the developers enough for the commitment they had to bringing a quality modern-day successor to old-school crpgs. The game literally feels like it combined the best and most complex systems of older rpgs, and then upgraded them while adding a few original twists to them. It has the tactical combat of something like the temple of elemental evil (perhaps a bit more streamlined, but superior in depth and challenge), the interactive world of something like fallout 1 or 2 (but again, with much better implemented and more varied systems), the lore and scope of the likes of baldur's gate 2, and more than a few new ideas of its own to keep things interesting. And most importantly, everything ties in well together to form a coherent, consistent sand box of rpg experimentation. Be warned however! This game requires an insane commitment of time and attention. There are so many things to micromanage. But that is exactly what I love about it. It is not a simple matter of grinding until your numbers are high enough. It rewards patience, exploration, experimentation and careful decision making. It is entirely possible to screw yourself over completely in this game... which again, makes for an awesome role playing experience. Progress does not come swiftly or at a steady pace. There may long stretches of time when you are just trying to figure out the best way to outfit your characters. You might spend an hour navigating a house full of traps and figuring out how to get all of the loot without blowing yourself up. You might spend some time learning recipes and crafting items. You might be reloading the same battle 5-10 times. There are literally endless possibilities of both emergent and prescripted gameplay...I can only hope that Larian studios, as well as other developers, get the message and start making more games like these.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												After 15 hours: If you like classic, turn-based RPGs (Fallout, Torment), take a look at this.The combat is a new and cool approach to turnbased combat, and works really well. And the difficulty level is just perfect! You will continually get that epic win feeling, when you engage in combat with greater enemies.The quests feel like they have meaning and are interesting, instead of the typical "kill these guys" or "get these things". There is not even a quest log, but just a journal that summarizes what you "already know". Basically just a reminder. You know... like a real journal? So you have to figure out YOURSELF, what the "quest" really is. It's heavily based on dialogue, and sometimes you have to really understand the purpose of the game's characters to know who to talk to about a certain quest. 'Cause the game wont tell you! Some dialogues even put you in really difficult moral decisions. Who gets to live, the young loner or the old family man? Should these soldiers be allowed to say they killed the monsters, even though you did, you they can get home to their families? More than once, I've stepped away from the computer to ponder my decisions.Oh yeah, and it's got co-op, which I haven't tried yet. But so far, I have a feeling it would work really well. The dialogues are sometimes between your companions and you have actual discussions that have big effects on the outcome of a quest.I've only played this for 15 hours total, so let's see if it can keep it up.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												If you're a fan of oldschool style rpgs then pick this game up. The combat is extremely tactical and fun. It feels like I'm playing the fastest paced game of Dungeons and Dragons ever, with the computer doing all the rolls for me. The graphics are beautiful and the environments have good ambiance. The music is excellent. It also seems to have an absolutely huge world with a ton of playtime. The randomly generated items make the loot exciting and gives you a ton of freedom in your character's customization.The drop in co-op is great. You start the game with two main characters so one other player can join your game at any time. This makes it easy for friends who play different total amounts of time to still play together. The quests are very funny at times and the game leaves you to explore rather than guiding you straight to the objectives (there are no quest markers in this game). Your choice gives you various personality traits that give stat bonuses which makes those choices feel more meaningful.Buy it if this even somewhat sounds good, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I'm 44 years old. My first favorite game was "Adventure" on the Atari 2600. Every time I learn a new aspect of this game, and gain insight into its breadth, I can tell it was honed by RPG fans that love the genre. It's open, expansive, and virtually every nook is filled with something to discover. It is paced to your liking through turned based afairs, which are painfully welcome. The voice acting is wonderul, the spaces are large, the interactions are fluid, the turn-based combat is engaging, there are mountains of equipment to find, etc.. My only wishes would center around aspects that understandably needed to be worked around due to the amount of time to accomplish that had dwindgling returns. Things like an optimized 360 view or voice acting all dialogue (2 additional months!), etc..  However, these are mere wishes, cherries on a a sundae. My personal utopia, sort of thing. Otherwise, I am having a blast and cherish the time I have at night to enjoy playing. I've only just begun, but I am already regretting that it will end. I only hope this is a "new" beginning of a wonderful franchise that will continue building upon this legacy. A clearly talented team, cheers to the future, now get back to work making bigger and better worlds in which we can all enjoy!

								This is my view. The game so far is very fun and creative but lacking which is no suprise considering it is an alpha. I'm enjoying the games spell and skill animations which are very colorful and cool. The games character customization is lacking in customization, appearance wise, but there are many traits to choose presently that all seem to serve a very recognizable purpose such as being useful for a mage or warrior and some that help your dialogue choices and the one I've found to be the most unique is the one that gives you the ability to talk to animals. I hope that add more unique traits in the future as well as making a very rounded character customization so i can make my character look how i want. Right now even though it is early alpha I have been able to delve into the classless part of the game. Such as having my mage use a two handed spear or teaching my rogue to use earth spells. The whole process doesn't seem to be completely fleshed out but it works well for alpha. So if you think that you want to support this game I believe it is worth your time and money. Remember that the game is in ALPHA and that the guys at Larian ar working to make this the game we all know it can be so give it some time and faith.

												This is -NOT- an aRPG.  This is on old-school flavored cRPG taking queues for the likes of Divine Divinity, Baldur's Gate 1-2 and the Ultima series.  Combat in this game is decisively turn-based, and for the better.  You have to play it smart and cool in D:OS, do not be upset when the game (rather constantly) tells you that you may adjust the difficulty to a lesser setting.  Well done, Larian.  It's good to get some usage out of your brain every once-in-a-while.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												If you like non-linear RPGs where you can do quests in any order, this is not your RPG. Every area has enemies levelled in a way that funnels you in specific ways. If you ignore these, you will find quests that can't be completed (because you never triggered the "please find this item" part and now that you already have it, you can't tell the quest giver about it), or non-sensical dialog: "Who is X?" (where X is a boss you have already spoken to, and killed), or "Y is summoning undead? He must be stopped!" (When you have already dealt with Y). Nothing game-breaking encountered yet - just a few quests stuck as 'unfinished' which also means less XP.Otherwise, the combat is fun - mixing elements or figuring out ways to dispose of enemies the best, and some of the puzzles are decent too. A decent old-school type RPG, but needs a little more work on the quest system.

												I had no idea this game would take me 152 hours to complete!  It was immersive and exactly what I had hoped for as a spiritual cousin of Baldur's Gate.  I completed it single player and now can't wait to try it multiplayer coop.  I probably could have finished it earlier if I hadn't become so engrossed in the crafting and loot management - I'm totally a RPG hoarder!  The combat was tactical and balanced, sometimes very challenging.  I was at a loss occasionally on how to complete quests, but there are good guides to reference online.  Overall, this is an absolute favorite that I highly recommend to any RPG fan.

												This game is great, period. Anyone thats looking for old school type of RPG with some modern touch, aka BG2 in 2014, this is for you. Would have liked to have a longer compaign, as you can really finish the main story line in 20-25hrs, I managed to squeeze out about 55hrs by trying to hit all the side quests which are entertaining but can be easily missed if you arent going out of your way to do them. content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												After spending the last week playing this game, I can safetly say that DOS is an extremely addicting and engaging game that I would highly recommend. Some of my favorite aspects were the voice acting, story, and also the sheer amount of exploration you can do. Most of the characters (including the random animals you encounter) were very interesting and added to the story. However, this game isn't perfect, the ending I feel could have been expanded more and there is a lack of end game (There isn't one [If this is a spoiler, sorry!]). I also found myself spending an incredible amount of time sorting through my inventory and trying to find vendors to sell the tons of armor I collected. Lastly, I do wish there was a bit more direction or help, especially in the last few areas where I spent hours trying to solve the puzzles and some of them I may have accidently solved because of bugs.Overall, this game is definitely a winner in my eyes and for players who enjoy games such as Diablo, Dragon Age, Elder Scrolls, etc. this is one that shouldn't be missed.

Early Access Review
								This game is amazing. It's still in "early access", I can play less than a quarter of the game and yet I've already spent over ten hours on it. The only thing holding me back is the fact that I know my saves will be wiped.It feels like a flawless mix of Temple of Elemental Evil, Neverwinter Nights (both of them) and Baldur's Gate, modernised. It is also slightly reminiscent of Runescape.- classless, free-form skills and abilities- turn-based combat- in-depth roleplaying - not only do your interactions with others affect your character, but your interaction with other party members can also boost certain stats depending on your personalityAll in all, fantastic game that I can see myself coming back to for years to come.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Did you ever want a sequel to the Baldur's Gate games, but felt like they'd need to really be retooled and modernized to make it a viable option to today's gamer?  Perhaps update the multiplayer system to make it truly multiplayer, or the combat system to become fully turn-based rather than stop-and-go command issuing, or even a deeper system of inventory and skill/spell usage?  Look no further, Larian has heard your cries for the antiquated gaming series to make a comeback in a new, pretty package with a brilliant leap forward in fantasy turn-based top-down RPGs.The Brilliant:- Crafting and blacksmithing is a thing, rather than just collecting an inventory full of junk items to sell later.  Sure, sell them if you like, but could that butter knife be used for something really cool other than gold fodder?- Identification of magic items is a breeze.  There's a skill for it, and items have an ID level.  It's that simple.  No more identification spells, or paying a week's adventurer's wages to get something ready for trade or use.- True multiplayer means not having a hacked together system, and its absolutely seamless here.  You can assign control over PCs or NPCs to your second player, and have a grand old time making sure you help each other.  Or not, if you're cruel.  Bonus points?  You DO NOT HAVE TO STICK TOGETHER.  Remember when you had to share your screen, and sticking close sometimes meant waiting ages for someone else?  Go wander six buildings over if you want.  Get things done twice as fast in town.The Good:- Gameplay and questing is fun, and leaves little to be desired.  The quests are difficult, the monsters and NPCs are challenging, and nothing is "dumbed down" unless you ask it to be by the difficulty setting.  Even then, you have to be witty to solve some of these quests, so bring your smart cap.- Dialogue and interaction are excellent.  What you tend to want out of an RPG is, oddly, all the RP - this game does not disappoint at all.  Sometimes serious, sometimes light-hearted, and as always, a bit of Larian humor in the mix, the game is entirely too happy to provide all the right tones in the right places.- Familiarity is amazing once you jump in.  If you're used to this style of game, you shouldn't feel left out at all (with one exception, see below).The Ok to Bad:While an excellent game, there are just a few things to watch out for...- The crafting system is potentially baffling straight out of the gate.  Prepare for long hours (or internet search engines) to help you build up your new crafting skills.  It can leave some players behind, and I know it frustrated at least one friend.  I loved it once I understood some of the premises.  Read those books you pick up!- Pathing options can be limited, and sometimes, combat makes it worse.  Be very, very particular with where you click and how you click.  Errant spells, randomly stepping in poison, or missing a backstab and moving instead are just a few of the problems that are normal because of the click to move style gaming.  One of my biggest issues is that NPCs duck/swivel/move while standing to make them more life-like, but because of that, sometimes you miss a click on them when trying to strike and end up moving (and subsequently wasting some action points because of it!)- Too much "excess noise" in populated areas means you may miss what your partner is saying or hearing.  NPCs that have side-conversation, or are yelling things in a market, show up on your dialogue space.  This quickly scrolls off potentially far more important information for quests.  Be prepared to read fast, or scroll a lot, especially in multi-player when you're not the one controlling the dialogue.Overall, despite my few complaints, this game is by far worth picking up.  My wife and I have enjoyed playing multi-player together beginning to end, and are likely to got through a second time once we've completed the DLC just to get a different PC perspective.  I can't wait for continued DLC, and to see how far this game goes as becoming the successor and champion of this style and genre mix.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												[Partial Review based on 60+ hours in the game and being in the 2nd act (of 4/5 acts?) of the game]They say time flies when you're having fun, and boy, has time been flying. Really glad I backed this game on Kickstarter, and the released product doesn't fail to live up to expectations. That's not to say the game at release isn't perfect - there are a couple of crashing bugs here and there but Larian is patching them fast (releasing micro-patches on a daily basis). There are also some bugs/polish issues and areas that could use refinement, particularly with the henchman system - although a part of the problem is a side effect of having much of the henchman being designed by Kickstarter backers before Larian changed the skills/talent tree substantially late in beta. And boy the present (limited) companions in this game at the moment are nothing like the many memorable companions of Bioware RPGs (here, they're pretty much one-dimensional, extremeist, dislikeable) but at the end of the day there are a ton MORE things that this game does right than wrong and it all comes together to equate tons of fun. And FWIW all the major systems do work well.Note that combat can be quite hard if you're not used to turn-based tactical combat, but once you figure out various game mechanics (via making lots of mistakes at first and possibly dying), things become managable even while challenging. Boss battles are immensely satisfying too (the first act's final boss makes you go "WTF!!" with all the thing it throws at you (literally lol) but I got this immense sense of satisfaction when I finally emerged out of that battle with 0 deaths on my first attempt).I expect this game to only get better overtime as Larian continues to support this post-game.Overall: Strongly recommend particularly if you like cRPGs, exploration, and/or turn-based tactical combat.

Posted: July 23, 2014
												My buddy and I started a new game, a couple of wayfaring adventurers looking to make a living 'n what not. Our first quest is to investigate the murder of a counselor.      In the midst of our investigation, we determine 4 suspects - one of which being the town healer's apprentice. We went to go question her on the matter but found her in the middle of treating two patients in dire condition. She had a strange stone in her possession that could possibly heal one of them of all ailments, but we would have to choose which one would receive the treatment. My partner and I discussed it, and after a rousing game of rock, paper, scissors, we decided that the younger of the two should be spared an early death.      After the healer's apprentice used the stone, it suddenly went haywire and transported my partner and I to another dimension where we were greeted by an imp claiming to be a historian - an archivist on all of time. He mentioned he had finished recording all of history, and told us to look through his giant looking glass. We peered through, and witnessed the end of all things. The universe being sucked into a void. After seeing this, the imp told us he wants to stop time from ending - save the world, y'know. Then he took us to a woman who had a giant, golden tapestry behind her.      This woman was time itself, and wove time together within that tapestry. She told us that neither of us were bound by time, that we instead, create time, and are the keys of saving time itself. After accepting a quest to gather "Star Stones to save time", we were given a teleportation pyramid that we could use to leave the dimension we were in and return to our own.      Upon using it, we found ourselves back in town, in a woman's house, where said woman was taking a bath and screamed at us to get back. My partner initiated rock, paper, scissors to convince her we're here for a good reason, but lost sorrily, and we immediately vacated the premises and continued our investigation.   On top of all that, the combat is complex, yet simple. Easy to understand, but just really deep in strategy. We got into a fight with about 7 monsters that happened to be a couple levels higher than us and we decided to make a tactical retreat while having our wizard character consistently teleport enemies and electrify pools of water for them to run into until we could get them close enough to the city gate where we could call upon some of the town guard to help us so we wouldn't get our butts reemed.     Character customization is what you'd expect from a classic-style RPG such as this: Multiple appearence alterations, and complete freedom in choosing what stats to put points into. My partner is a geomancy using wayfarer who also uses oils and poisons to incapacitate enemies, while I, being a knight, run around with a giant weapon crushing the skulls of my enemies, but have foregone most of the healing abilities set in the begining to up my power in combat.     The game truly came alive for me when I started to have that "Baldur's Gate experience." Where it wasn't just another RPG, but it felt more like an adventure. The possibilities still seem endless, and even though we haven't seemed to make much progress, it hasn't become a chore to run around and talk to NPCs, barter with each and every one of them to see what loot they might be willing to part with, or see what the latest gossip is, yielding other quests to be found simply through exploration and inquiry. And the amount of player interaction found not only between the players and the enviornment, but also the players themselves (should you play co-op) is absolutely fantastic.    Divinity: Original Sin is for those who are looking for a good, well developed, in-depth classic CRPG that fans of D&D and Baldur's Gate can appreciate. And with custom campaigns being available, the game has a near limitless potential.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
Pros:GraphicsThe environment design is superbly done. The level of details on the character models and environmental effects are very good and help with the immersion. If you have a decent enough graphics card, crank up the detail level to get the best experience.Combat SystemStacking spells is fun and the results can be surprising sometimes. The ability to use the environment is a big plus as well. The turn-based combat allows you to plan out your attack/defense without frantic button mashing.StoryThe lore and story is pretty good. Some very funny moments in there as well.Length and PacingSomehow it feels "just right". It's not too level-grindey nor is it too fast-paced.ConsNon-linearity breaks some story elementsDue to the fact that you can progress your own way without a set path, some story elements can break and you are often left wondering, "Did I leave something out?"Crafting systemI find it is a bit disappointing that you cannot craft items with legendary stats and some item crafting combinations do not really make sense when you think about it. Overall, it feels quite dodgy and forced. Some item combinations that you would expect to work just don't, (e.g., Mysterious Dye, adding elemental damage to some weapons)These two cons aside, this is a very good CRPG.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is by far one of the more entertaining games I have played in the last couple of years. It has all of the challenge of old-school turn-based combat from games like Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights with the added fun factor of Magicka's spell/environment combinations. You can opt for any number of different class combinations in your game; so, don't feel like magic is a must. You start the game with two main characters that you can build out any way you like (there are pre-configured classes or you can make your own). Once you make your way into the first town, you are free to recruit two additional henchmen to help fill out your group. Whether you want two warriors and two mages, or two rogues a paladin and a ranger, the choice is yours. The co-op gameplay is just as fun as playing solo, although following the dialog can be more difficult. The introduction of the co-op conversation system can make for some entertaining outcomes. For example, if you decide you want to be the nice guy; but, your friend wants to play a villain.Overall it is an excellent game, one of the few I would recommend to my friends.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												This game is an awesome role playing game. It feels a lot like Ultima 7 but in 2014 3D glory, the graphics are crisp and the world is alive, detailed and interesting. The combat is turn based, but it's very natural as fights take place in the same environments your exploring with no transition of any sort. There are tons of abilities and spells to keep combat interesting and varied. There are tons of items and a lot of work has gone into making things interactive. You can craft items from logical bits and pieces if you want. They've also done a great job at environment effects, water puts out fire, fire sets oil ablaze, eletricity electrocutes wet things, you can smash things or be steathly. You can attack innocents and skulk around stealing stuff. Larian has really outdone themselves. I've heard co-op has been done very well with both players playing a real role in the game and both get to take part in various conversations. Thank you Larian Studios.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Another fine RPG from Larian studios, but not without it's faults.Original Sin is a very open ended RPG, and truly they have succeeded on this front, almost to a fault. No areas are off limits and it's very easy to stumble into an area quite over the party's head. The game is built around these freedoms and the engine and game systems in place do a fantastic job at allowing you those freedoms. There was one point where this freedom was troublesome for me, and I eventally arrived at a point where I was unable to progress and unsure why. Some google research led me to a "quest" (not in my journal) that I needed to do in order to do another thing... to do another thing... to progress in the story. I don't want to give more details, as it would be spoilers, but needless to say there probably should have been a quest entry for the initial "wall" that I hit.All that aside, the game is very well done. The combat is fun and the enviornmental interaction is all top notch. The skills are interesting and you can make quite a few different types of characters. Combining spell effects leads to interesting combinations and allows you to think outside the box in order to overcome battles that may have otherwise been too difficult for your party.What the game makes up for in open-endedness, it lacks in story. The story isn't awful, by any means, but the above-mentioned "wall" that I hit made it so I basically put a pause on the story for 75% of the game and then was rushed through all of it hours before the finale. Sort of silly.Graphics are good, writing is acceptable, and I encountered very few bugs.Overall, would recommend, but don't feel bad if you have to look at a guide online a few times.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I'm 44 years old. My first favorite game was "Adventure" on the Atari 2600. Every time I learn a new aspect of this game, and gain insight into its breadth, I can tell it was honed by RPG fans that love the genre. It's open, expansive, and virtually every nook is filled with something to discover. It is paced to your liking through turned based afairs, which are painfully welcome. The voice acting is wonderul, the spaces are large, the interactions are fluid, the turn-based combat is engaging, there are mountains of equipment to find, etc.. My only wishes would center around aspects that understandably needed to be worked around due to the amount of time to accomplish that had dwindgling returns. Things like an optimized 360 view or voice acting all dialogue (2 additional months!), etc..  However, these are mere wishes, cherries on a a sundae. My personal utopia, sort of thing. Otherwise, I am having a blast and cherish the time I have at night to enjoy playing. I've only just begun, but I am already regretting that it will end. I only hope this is a "new" beginning of a wonderful franchise that will continue building upon this legacy. A clearly talented team, cheers to the future, now get back to work making bigger and better worlds in which we can all enjoy!

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Divinity: Original Sin is one of the most rewarding RPGs to come along in years. Its quests and combat compelled me to think hard about my actions and choices, which is more than I usually get to say about contemporary RPGs. Its depth, personality, and combat challenges easily allow it to hold its own against the likes of heavyweights like Dragon Age: Origins. These systems invite constant experimentation throughout dozens of memorable hours of combat and cheeky storytelling, and its rich modding toolkit provides the framework for enjoyable player-made adventure for years to come.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												If you are looking for a perfect mix of RPG, turn based combat (that doesn't feel clunky at all) and perfect scenarios and atmosphere, this game is for you!I suggest this game particularly if you're a fan of Dragon Age: Origins as the two feel very alike but don't be doubtful because of its price: this game is VERY polished and everything feels like it was meant to be. A quick list of pros of this game:1) The landscapes and characters feel very alive and the world is a TRUE fantasy world. You will be astounded by what can happen at any time.2) The lore is rich and refined, if you are into it.3) The graphics are gorgeous, as I said, for landscapes but also for spells and monsters.4) There are ALOT of ways to build your character. Will it be a healer? A tank? A hybrid? Maybe you're into battlemages? There are alot of presets from which to choose and modify to your liking. To mention a few: Shadowblade, Battlemage, Enchanter, Witch, Knight and so on.5) Great interactivity with the world around you. Move objects with your brute strength or spend some points into Telekinesis: you will need it to solve enigmas in the dungeons or to set a trap with a nearby explosive barrel that you can later ignite.6) The combat is also very well polished: turn based, use actions points for different abilities or save them up each turn.7) Last, but not least, the game has an awesome editor that allows you to create all kinds of adventures. It feels a bit like the Warcraft3 editor, if you get the reference.Totally worth the price!

												This RPG is a masterpiece. Period. And I even thought that I didn't like turn-based combat. Warning: This is absolutely NOT a Diablo-like game (though I have nothing against Hack & Slash genre). The only similarity is the isometric perspective. content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												I've ♥♥♥♥ed around with computer role-playing games since I was a snotty little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ creeping around Service Merchandise, begging my parents for a Commodore 64. I've experienced such things as Temple of Apshai, Muse's original 2-D Castle Wolfenstein, and innumerable titles from Strategic Simulations Incorporated. Now, while all you folks don't have reason to know me from Adam's housecat, let me assure you of one thing: it is damn certain that I know how to have fun on those crazy computer machines.Divinity: Original Sin takes me back to the happy days when I was a little punk who could spend twelve hours at a time in front of a console television the size of a dreadnought, chain-smoking filterless Camels and min-maxing the hell out of whatever 8-bit avatar caught my fancy.Original Sin makes me feel like I've gone back to the glory days of dicking around with a crazy old computer game that was made by fanatical autists. It makes me feel the unadulterated fun that I once knew, back when I was just a jerk-off little kid who didn't have a care in the world beyond reaching maximum entertainment saturation. If you want to feel what it is like to experience Baldur's Gate squared combined with The Incredible Machine cubed, you should snag yourself a copy of this game. It is like cooking down a spoonful of SSI and shooting it straight into your jugular.And damn, who is this musician who did the soundtrack to Divinity: Original Sin? I know that he's been working with Larian since the Bronze Age, but I haven't felt as motivated by game music since I heard some dirty♥♥♥♥♥sawtooth waves and hypnotizing ring-modulated main riffs blasting out of a SID chip. Larian's personal Beethoven could hold his own against composers like Alexander Brandon and Damjan Mravunac.Buy the Hell out of this game. You won't regret it, unless you're a ♥♥♥♥♥.

content:

Early Access Review
								It only took 5-10 minutes of just exploring the first area for me to reconfirm to myself that crpgs are my favorite genre. I had a blast in my 5 hours of play and the fact that this is just alpha makes me that more excited. Once this game is patched up and polished it's going to be awesome.I was first turned off by the idea of turn based combat as the old FF-like combat came to mind however after a few fights it didn't phase me at all. I love the attention to detail and all the ways we can interact with the evironment. The combination of these is gonna lead to some rather unexpected and hilarious memorable moments. Already had one where one of my mains got thrown in jail for attempting to cook a pizza in some dude's fireplace. That town has some strict laws... It taught me to be mindful of where I test out some of the game's features or maybe not.I'm probably going to wait until they enable character customization before I play more. Really looking forward to creating the mains to how I want... already getting ideas for when release comes around.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is my view. The game so far is very fun and creative but lacking which is no suprise considering it is an alpha. I'm enjoying the games spell and skill animations which are very colorful and cool. The games character customization is lacking in customization, appearance wise, but there are many traits to choose presently that all seem to serve a very recognizable purpose such as being useful for a mage or warrior and some that help your dialogue choices and the one I've found to be the most unique is the one that gives you the ability to talk to animals. I hope that add more unique traits in the future as well as making a very rounded character customization so i can make my character look how i want. Right now even though it is early alpha I have been able to delve into the classless part of the game. Such as having my mage use a two handed spear or teaching my rogue to use earth spells. The whole process doesn't seem to be completely fleshed out but it works well for alpha. So if you think that you want to support this game I believe it is worth your time and money. Remember that the game is in ALPHA and that the guys at Larian ar working to make this the game we all know it can be so give it some time and faith.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								I backed this game, to date they have given me 54 updates as to their progress. Not just a wall of text either, this company has made a ton of youtube videos and allowed everyone to get an inside look into their game development. Their forums are spotted with feedback and bug reports and almost every post acknowledged and replied to! They have really tried to keep the public involved in the making of their product and I have been super excited to see their finished game.I just recently decided to delve into the Alpha build and am 100% pleased with my wait.  Reminds me of a mix of Baldur's Gate one and two, which is amazing. The music is unique, dialogue is of course a little cliche but sprinkled with humor. The game doesn't completely hold your hand which I love and brings me back to my play throughs of some great originals (Baldurs Gate, Neverwinter Nights, Dungeon Siege 1, Return to Krondor, Ultima). The story is also Co-Op which I haven't tried.TL:DRPick this game up if you are sick of crappy console ports and want a fun RPG that isn't completely baby proof and you enjoy games such as Baldur's Gate, Ultima, etc etc.
