number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												If you're a fan of oldschool style rpgs then pick this game up. The combat is extremely tactical and fun. It feels like I'm playing the fastest paced game of Dungeons and Dragons ever, with the computer doing all the rolls for me. The graphics are beautiful and the environments have good ambiance. The music is excellent. It also seems to have an absolutely huge world with a ton of playtime. The randomly generated items make the loot exciting and gives you a ton of freedom in your character's customization.The drop in co-op is great. You start the game with two main characters so one other player can join your game at any time. This makes it easy for friends who play different total amounts of time to still play together. The quests are very funny at times and the game leaves you to explore rather than guiding you straight to the objectives (there are no quest markers in this game). Your choice gives you various personality traits that give stat bonuses which makes those choices feel more meaningful.Buy it if this even somewhat sounds good, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								[Personal View]I kickstarted this game because it looked promosing but I am not buyest, (even if it seems so) I did took the risk betting on a promise. And so far it seems to have gone well for this company. This game has it hits and misses but the one thing that amazes me is the lack of originality (In this case it's a good thing). The fact that the company took the easiest concept and turned it into something more is mind blowing.If Steam let's me update this "Review" (it's a review of a preview that's an alpha, which helds no merit or credits what so ever besides the joy of a guy that bought the product).[Review (of a Preview that's an alpha)]The setup is great, it's a clean enviroment that helps the player see the things that needs to be seen. This can even work against you because you might miss something if you don't check it out. I don't know if it was made that was or that this is an alpha but somethings on the screen makes you believe it's an object you can investigate or do so exploration is an option.The Dialog is the main feature for this game (the way I see it), with the dialog you can roleplay a step further by building up the character you wish to be. With that said the brilliant idea has been set up to bring a companion with you and play with you and that companion CAN be a real player. Obviously it leads to interesting developments because the partner can shape drama/action/personalities with you. You or your partner doesn't always have to agree towards one another, with that you can use to your parties advantage in different ways.My opinion of this mechanic is what defines this game genre, "True Co-operative game". For a preview for this game it's really shaping up to be a good game, but they do need to polish the bugs and the plenty of issues the game have (yeah, an alpha game that has bugs and issues, who would of known).

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
Divinity: Orignal Sin - The party based, truly oldschool CRPG you were looking forIn short: Larians latest instalment of the Divinity series proofs many publishers and devs wrong that think the only way to sell games these days is by dumbing them down as far as possible. Original Sin proofs the we gamers still very much enjoy games that keep the hand-holding to a minimum and let us explore the world on our own. It proofs that turn-based combat systems still work, that modern technology hasn't made them obsolete and that not every RPG has to be a clone of Diablo (1 and 2, not the bad one). Disclaimer: I am only 30 hours inI guess I should mention that I've only played the game for about 30 hours at the moment. I am almost done with the first of the four acts but I haven't seen the whole game yet. So, keep in mind, everything written here is based on that. I will update this review every time I finish another act.Truly OldschoolIt's sad that I feel the need to start with this, but, given how the term 'oldschool' has been abused in the recent years, it's better to be safe than sorry. 'Oldshool' doesn't mean you just use the name of an old franchise. It's not about making people that remember great games from their youth believe that your game will be similar to their somewhat romantic memories of days long gone past. And Larian gets that. What they made is a game that might not share the name of the great series of our childhood but it still feels like Ultima, Baldur's Gate or maybe even Neverwinter Nights. Divinity: Original Sin is the kind of CRPG you played back in the day.Open World ...  ish ... ?Original Sin has some Open World elements but it also can be extremely linear. This might sound controversial at first, but it truly isn't. In fact, when you ask me, the game perfectly combines the best elements from both worlds. The game is linear cos it is story-driven. There are certain things you have to do in a particular order to progress, you can't just roam through the world and explore what's going on. Well, technically you could but you probably would just end up being crushed by enemies that are way above your level. This may sound discouraging at first, especially if you are used to games like Skyrim, but on the other hand it allows for better storytelling. Okay, the story itself is not that great (at least not so far), but it still benefits from the games linear nature.The open world aspect of the game comes in form of character development and the way quests are handled. When building a character you can pretty much do what you want, your mage can wear heavy armour, your rouge can cast lightning spells to teleport across the battlefield and your warrior can summon spiders or fire elementals. Granted, not every combination is a good idea and if you want to create a jack-of-all-trades you will need to spread you skill points thin, but, if you want to, you can do it. Quests, except for the main quest line, are also very open. You can not only approach them in different ways but, based on what you do, the outcome will also differ. I can't really give you examples cos that would include spoilers, but pretty much every side quest has multiple possible endings and at least two, sometimes even four or more ways how you could do it. However, not all ways may be available to you cos some require certain skills.No Hand-holdingThe game does almost no hand-holding, at least not in the traditional sense of the term. There are (almost) no quest markers, no arrows that tell you where to go. Heck, sometimes quests only give you a vague idea of what you might have to do and then the game let's you figure it out on your own. This is appealing to a lot of us, but certainly not to everybody. Let's take the main story as an example. At the start of the game a note tells you that you have been ordered to go to Cyseal and investigate the murder of councillor Jake. That's it. You go through a short tutorial, enter Cyseal, are immediately given the opportunity to do some side quest and then you have to figure out what's going on. You have to talk to quite a few people, that are not highlighted with exclamation marks by the way, before you figure out what might have happened. However, if you do what the game wants you to do, if you talk to people, listen to their conversations and read the books you find, the game pretty much tells you what you have to do and when you have to do it. Pacing, Turn-based Combat and DifficultyTo some the pacing of Original Sin might seem too slow or off, but that's not entirely true. Granted, it takes you about 10 hours before fights start to become more interesting and you can spend a whole day running through Cyseal doing side quest that don't involve combat and just learn as much about the world as possible. So yes, if you are looking for combat the game might seem to start to slow for you, but then again, that's not what Original Sin is about.The game is a CRPG in the spirit of pen & paper RPGs like Das Schwarze Auge (engl: The Dark Eye), it is more about atmosphere and story-telling than about combat. It involves combat, a lot of it, but that's not the core mechanic.When you encounter enemies the combat is handled in turn-based mode. You get a nice "Fight!" displayed on the screen, your party takes position and then the combat starts. The order in which characters acts is determined by their initiative and once it's their turn they can't wait till later, so you have to ensure that your buff chars have a higher initiative than your damage dealers. How many actions a character can perform depends on his action points, the more he has the further he can walk, the more attacks he can make and so on. Unspent action points are not lost but carried over into the next round, up to a maximum of course. How difficult the game is depends heavily on how you play it. If you understand its mechanics and use them to your advantage the game can be pretty easy even on hard. Having a well rounded party also helps, 4 glass cannons won't help you, neither will 4 tanks. Elemental EffectsSo far combat doesn't sound very interesting, it's your basic CRPG turn-based stuff. However, there is more. In Original Sin you can combine elemental effects to your advantage. E.g. if you create a puddle of water - or blood - and then electrocute it with e.g. a lightning bolt everything in it will be stunned. If you let it rain fire elementals will be weaker and your chances to freeze enemies are higher, if you ignite a poison cloud it will explode and if you freeze liquids characters might slip on them (happened to the end boss of the first act, I almost fell out of my chair laughing).The FlawsOkay, so far I only mentioned the good stuff, but not game is perfect, here is a short list of the stuff Original Sin doesn't do that well:- there are only two companions that interact with you, the rest doesn't talk at all- some of the writing is really bad- pathfinding works differently in combat, your chars don't avoid deadly lava any more ConclusionBuy the game!

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												This game is awesome, a bit tough (if that worries you, easy is easy), it is very much like the Baldur's Gate and Ice Wind Dale series, a bit never winter night-ish as well.  I have been sinking time into this game and only just got it a few days ago.  It has totally consumed my game time and I've only played it single player.  I'd almost recommend putting 10-15 hours into the game and then starting over with new custom characters once you understand how everything works.  I feel like I could have started out with better stats now that I've got a bit of time played and understand the attributes, skills, talents, etc.  Also knowing the free characters you get early on would help prevent any early duplication in skills.  Lastly, at a certain point into the game you can really customize your party, although I've been really sticking with my first 4 and making it work.  I'm curious if and when I'll go pick up some new characters, been getting attached to the ones I have.  Can't recommend this game enough for any RPG fan, and without having to pay full price, yet feeling like you got a $50-$60 dollar game out of it.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Amazing adventure awaits those who dare to venture into the perils of Divinity: Original Sin. Survive the hard and unfair world by using your wits, courage, good looks and some good old fashion backbone while doing your best to not get impaled, dissected or melted.You expect handholding? You expect Navigator the fairy to come over and make you "listen" while freezing your game to mock your intelligence for the 1000th time? Guess again! Dive head first into an epic quest where all you have is your skill and wits to solve the ruthless, gut wrenching puzzles that, when solved,  will make you a real god among men.In addition prepare to battle the most wretched, cruel and evil monsters and enemies this side of the underworld as you fight your way to glory in a test of your ability to think tactically, plan ahead and kick♥♥♥♥♥But that's not all, not only will you face this incredible adventure, but you will take your comrades with you! Invite one of your most courageous friends to join you as you quest through this adventure of bilbical proportions, role play and work together to beat down the challenges you face thus becoming the ultimate blood brothers and sisters the world has ever seen, bonding in a degree enough to make Frodo and Sam lower their heads in shame.Not enough to convince you? Pick up the Digital Collectors edition and grab the best dlc goodies the game has to offer in the future right off the bat WHILE also grabbing yourself 2 copies of this fantastic adventure so you may gift the second copy to your most loyal comrade making them your best friend to all eternity.Guaranteed satisfaction to ANYONE looking for the adventure of a lifetime!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Without going into details, my condensed opinion;Game is well polished, unfinished but very fun and refreshingly new. $40's a bit much for the 10-15 that it has now, but I've no doubt it'll be worth it in the long run. As of now, the game's pretty buggy and not terribly well optimized. I expect all of that to change over some time, but it's got a lot of great concepts and ideas that you don't see in many other games. Your main characters [a girl and a guy, whose names presently escape me] will occassionally have dialogue oppertunities between one another which develop their characters very nicely, but work best when someone else is being one of the two. It's a bit difficult to explain, but it's very interesting and entertaining. An example would be you pick up an item that doesn't belong to you, and the characters enter into a debate as to whether it's right or not. You choose what each one says, so lets say one is okay with stealing and the other isn't. there's then a character test to see whose opinion wins out. It's fun on your own, and you can control what you want to happen as the player's selected character always wins, I think, but it's more interesting with a friend.The game also has some extremely well polished combat, which looks satisfying, and feels satisfying, but you do need to think to win. And I'll be honest, it's pretty tough. You can lose pretty easily, and there's a bit of a level wall, being that you can't beat certian monsters that you might run into in the early game due to your low level, but that can basically be avoided by following the quests. I'm told the game's got 10-15 hours of gameplay in it right now, and I can totally see that. I've clocked 4-5 hours in it on and offline, and it made for some fun when I was travelling, and on my desktop. Hell, it's got a replayable 10-15 hours as of right now. Just don't get too attached to your save file--being that it's in alpha, it's pretty likely it'll get corrupted along the line.Graphics wise, the game can actually be pretty intensive, and as I said, it's not that well optimized right now. But it looks really nice for a turn based strategy. And I mean REALLY nice. On max graphics, it's pretty damn gorgeous.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Potentially best Fantasy RPG since Dragon Age:OriginsDivinity has finally entered its beta stage, thus we get a good glimpse into what kind of game final release would be. One of its main appealing qualities is graphics, which have been further improved since alpha. textures, effects, details and animations all are beautiful and run smoothly even in games early stage.Game story starts off fascinating: in a world living under constant fear of "sourcery", two inqusitors set to investigate local murder. As they carry out their mission it becomes clear that a malevolent force is in motion here and murder is just a part of a much larger sceme. Unfortunately, story is quickly deteriorates to simple "save-the-world" scenario, from there on - not much to talk about. Somehow it is not the "big" things the game shines, but the details.Quests are plenty and fortunately not repeatetive at the moment, thanks to the deep game mechanics that allow to approach tasks differently. From what I've seen so far NPC personalities are fairly shallow, usually revolving around one characteristic, however they are still satisfying b/c dialogues revolve around two PC, each with its own personality and intricate dialogue options. Dialogue system is really smart. Faced a dilemma your PC's will trigger conversation with each other, and try to charm, reason or even intimidate each other into doing things their way. While it may seem easy as you can chose dialogue options and choose to always agree (and spare yourself some fascinating banter), you will also miss out on ability and social bonuses that develop through party communication. It is also important to pay attention to circumstances, not just "use your best ability" both in dialogues and combat. Dialogues feature "situational bonuses" which mean, that even if you're very intimidating you might not be able to threaten your way out of every encounter. Combat is a whole different story and though many in the past tried to incorporate certain levels of interactivity, D:OS is the first to nail it right. There's a lot of elements in the game and each of them has many ways to interact with others. Evaporate water or extinguish fire, burn through poisonous clouds or oiled surfaces. deep freeze or electrocute "wet" enemies. The possibilities do seem vast and well integrated, making a difference between easy battle and an unwinnable one.A lot of other features are implemented, such as sneaking, pickpocketing, crafting etc. There is a huge freedom in how you do things - almost every object in the game is interactible in some way. However it is delivered in a way that is not frustrating, as in some open-world games. Maybe its b/c game holds firm grasp on its story and you will never have to travel to the other side of the realm, just to find out you shoul've picked up that flask 10 hours ago. Anyway if, like me, you've been waiting for a good fantasy RPG, look no further. This may very well be the best to come since Dragon Age: Origins.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Amazing game so far. One again Larian Studios didnt let me down. It even features some characters i already knew from previous games, like Thelryon. Fantastic lore, fantastic atmosphere, awesome combat and customazation, loveable characters, multiplayer and last but not least, mod support and a level editor. What more can you ask for? A must buy for any RPG Fan out there, and if you havent played the older games in the series...do it. Youre missing out.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Both whimsical and incredibly complex, Divinity - Original Sin has a multitude of everything. Evolving your characters' personalities as they go, moving and adjusting nigh anything that isn't nailed down to the ground, a crafting system that's both intuitive and incredibly complex... and a story that I found myself thoroughly enjoying.I admit that I missed Divine Divinity, back in the day. Beyond Divinity was fairly dull and repetitive, so I gave up on it eventually, even though it had a fair share of complexity. Divinity - Dragon Knight Saga... it was nice, but only the expansion truly showcased what the game could have been, in terms of deep dialog and character design, complex questlines, and interesting gameplay.But here... here I got an RPG that was amazing. One that features no level scaling, one that does turn-based combat incredibly well. One that nailed down things like complex, multi-layered effects to one's choices even in battle.It's not perfect. A few areas could have been even more complex, sure. And I was never a fan of Diablo-style item randomization, preferring instead the more personalized and deep feel games like Baldur's Gate provided.But this is a masterpiece. And it deserves respect! Play it!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												When I purchased this game, it was late in Early-Access. I played it for a few hours, and got pretty into it - My inner tabletop gamer was let loose, like a famished lion at a steakhouse I chewed through the content.Little did I realize, what I was playing was only 1/4 of what awaited me at release.Release day rolled around, and I was like a little boy on Christmas Day, I couldn't wait to get home and start playing it.And when I did, my life was thrown out the window. I had a long weekend (Due to the holiday) and spent the entirety of it completely immersed in Rivelon (The world of divinity), shirking hygiene and all responsibility (save for family visits on the 4th) in order to complete my quest.Finally, at the end of day 5, I fought, and defeated the final boss of the game (Or so I thought) only to find out that that was only the end of the FIRST ACT.Something inside me broke, as I realized I had spent the better part of fourty hours working toward a goal that only amounted to a quarter of the game's overarching story.This game, it will be the death of me (or at least my marriage).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												I've played the game since Alpha and let me tell you this:This game is everything an adventurer wants, EVERYTHING.Exploration: 10/10Multiple ways of ending quests, dungeons with unique layed out traps with randomised loot, different exploration rewards, ... I can't even sum up what kind of treat this game is for exploration. If you want to check every single nook, crack, barrel and crate you may and it sometimes even rewards you. If you want to go dig graves for loot you can if you try. The best part? Most exploration is optional, the only complaint is that some quests do require some thought, but thats what you want, right... right?Combat: 9/10It's a classic DnD styled turn system expanded to the smallest detail. You use AP which you generate each turn to do all of your actions, be it slashing, burning, zapping, teleporting, buffing, debuffing, etc... (find out the rest yourself!)Fighting even takes places in a certain zone, so in multiplayer your partner could be shopping whilst you're fighting off the undead. It should be noted that when not in combat, there are no turns, you walk around and turns are taken on a timer if you're not in them.This does cause minor exploitation as your partner sneaks around for 5 minutes whilst you stare at the enemy.The game is also very unforgiving when it comes to making mistakes as you can ruin the entire fight by accidently clicking next to the enemy and run towards your grave.Story: 7/10Everything has a story, maybe not as intresting, maybe not as obvious, but its there. View quickly through it or read intensly, your choice.The game also has a system where you persuade NPC's, enemies or even your own partner. This system is called Rock, Paper, Scissors. The upside of the system allows players to have their characters interact with eachother, be it through Reason, Charm or Intimitating. The downside is when it comes to the NPC's the outcome actually matters much more as it can stop you from obtaining loot or important quest details.Look I'm just going to stop the review here and be glad if you even read this.This game is an adventurer's delight, reminds me of old Final Fantasy games like 6 and 10 crossed with DnD, except alot more awesome. I mean, come on, bleeding zombies with poisen trails, exploding gaint farts or oil barrels with fire magic, teleporting zombies that barf all over you away, fighting side by side with your comrades, FIGHT HORRIBLE AND VERY EVIL LOOKING DEMONS, WHY AM I NOT PLAYING THIS GAME? Because I already need to take the game very slowly, otherwise I might die from sheer awesomeness.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												When I purchased this game, it was late in Early-Access. I played it for a few hours, and got pretty into it - My inner tabletop gamer was let loose, like a famished lion at a steakhouse I chewed through the content.Little did I realize, what I was playing was only 1/4 of what awaited me at release.Release day rolled around, and I was like a little boy on Christmas Day, I couldn't wait to get home and start playing it.And when I did, my life was thrown out the window. I had a long weekend (Due to the holiday) and spent the entirety of it completely immersed in Rivelon (The world of divinity), shirking hygiene and all responsibility (save for family visits on the 4th) in order to complete my quest.Finally, at the end of day 5, I fought, and defeated the final boss of the game (Or so I thought) only to find out that that was only the end of the FIRST ACT.Something inside me broke, as I realized I had spent the better part of fourty hours working toward a goal that only amounted to a quarter of the game's overarching story.This game, it will be the death of me (or at least my marriage).

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												For years I've been waiting for an RPG to even come close to giving me what the Baldur's Gate series did. After playing around 10 hours of Divinity: Original Sin, I'm still waiting. I hoped for a game full of great dialogue, and smart combat. The combat comes close, but this is one of those games where every single battle must be approached with great care. That's fine  ... and fun too ... if the game isn't too combat heavy. Too many hard fought battles bog down progression, especially early in a game before the story really has a chance to hook the player. My characters feel underpowered in comparison to the enemy, and every enemy seems to have an endless arsenal of poison/fire arrows.In situations such as these battles become a chore. Sadly, the storyline and quests don't dull that blow. I found the quests confusing. Often I felt I'd spoken to all parties involved in a quest and gotten nowhere. Subsequent attempts at conversing unlocked no new dialogue. Plus, NPC's can become angry or offended when confronted with suspicion, adding an additional hurdle to completion. There are definitely some good ideas here andI realize a lot of people love this game. I'm definitely not one of them.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												This game is seriously overrated, played more than 50 hours and most of them were you guessed it, running around looking for quests or reloading after some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that goes in combat.Baldur's Gate had great gameplay, this game doesn't, to start you must use elements to win and for that you need to be a mage one way or the other, warriors, archers and rogues are screwed if they don't use elements, plus the system is further flawed when you realize that there is no freedom, you must follow the same path all the time yet because it is "old school" it gets a free card, you must do the damn quests in town ( all linked mind you) to be able to stand a chance against overpowered enemies.                        Another gameplay flaw, poor AI that has to be made up with enemies always being stronger and numerous than you that on top of that will casts crowd control spells  on you max 4 min 2 members, in fact this game can only be won by abusing of CC, try to take on enemies with meele, ranged and magic that has no crowd control ( no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t stunned, freezing and slipping, smoke and any other), you'll get stomped all the damn time.Lets not forget the wonderful loot that is randomnised like in a ARPG, so unless you are lucky, keep reloading to abuse the system.There is far more to say, for instance useless and too few talents, non-sensical trait system, the skill and attribute system making hybrids or any custom class crap, constant misclicking, bad UI, the  long and long battles ( all the same every playthrough, no random encounters), the bad mapping, bugs and glitches, bad crafting system and lack of deph in the world, you will fight undead most of the time, with the same tactics, same weapon types, same companions, same awful story and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ same slow movement and animation!

number of helpful: 30 of 61 people (49%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												I really wanted to enjoy this game, in fact on some level I do like this game. But it feels as if the game is deliberatly attempting to annoy me while playing it.Pros-The combat system really is good, despite the way it's actually utilized.-Art style and spell effects both look quite nice.-Enviormental effects add depth to the game.Cons-The UI is terrible in more than one way. Character inventory is particuraly bad and very messy to navigate.-Along with the UI itself, the game does a poor job of displaying combat information. Sometimes the game doesn't respond to tell me an individual is stunned or will show I'm safe from a reaction shot, when I am not in fact safe.-The terrain just doesn't work at all. You can LOS enemies simply by being anywhere near a wall, it doesn't matter if you're actually out of shown view or not. The very same applies to height. This is particularly bad when using and postioning an archer, sometimes the mouse will randomly move on it's own resulting in a needless miss.-The game is deceptively linear. Despite giving you no set objectives you have to progress in a painfully specific order. If you attempt to break from the order the game in no way displays you will either die to something more powerful than you, or the quest will not progress as you have deviated from the hidden order.-Classes seem terribly imbalanced. The problem is you have no way to know that either one of your characters could be quite useless, or your combination just doesn't work. This is discovered hours after creation, far beyond any point of fixing the issue. I have to ask why even give me the option to create characters if the classes aren't balanced? I would've rather had fairly balanced Source Hunters, created by the developers to provide an adequeate response to the game's challenges.-Combat relies far too much on cc. There is precisely one tactic that works, cc spam the enemy so they lose the ability to do the same to you. Which in my opinion is just lazy. This futher adds onto the problem of class imbalance, given that if one of your created characters has weak cc capability then you're screwed.-Enemies overwhem you with numbers and stun/freeze spam as opposed to knowledge of tactics, and differing mechanics.-You can literally fail side quests from a lost conversation dice roll between your characters. This is so laughable that I'm not sure there is much else I can even say to express just how arbitrary and ridiculous this "mechanic" results in being.There are a few other things that have annoyed me, but I think listing anything further would take away from what I feel are the game's objective negatives.Despite my review, I don't hate this game. This is just a title that I incorrectly assumed I would very much enjoy, instead of struggling to discover a single thing about it I may actually find somewhat tolerable.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Ok, I played through this game 3 times and invested over 400 hours into it so I think I can give an honest review. I really can't say I don't recommend it but I have a love hate relationship with it instead. First off, you can't beat this game without a walk-through. I don't care what other reviewers say, there are puzzles that are so counter-intuitive that you literally would have to spend an eternity trying out every possible permutation to eventually come across the correct combination so you can progress.  In addition there are so many game breaking mistakes you can make from poor character builds to killing the wrong person that the chances of doing everything right borders on impossible.  The story is boring and convoluted leaving you little reason to even care about your character. So why did I play it 3 times? Gameplay. This game has some of the most fun game mechanics I've ever experienced. Battles are truly fun requiring some serious strategy and if you do a correct built, you can do epic damage even to the most daunting boss. I really hope someone uses this engine to create the story this game deserves. With a good writing team this easily could have rivaled Baulders Gate or Fallout.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												If you ever looked upon baulder's gate, icewind dale, fallout tactics, and thought of the days of wooden cars and Fred Flintstone, and wanted something a few decades newer with modern game mechanics, this is it.This Isometric immersion vessel is christened to be the best RPG to ever float your camera in a bird's eye view. So hop on board and lets set sail into the best 80 hour journey abroad the vintage western RPG hemisphere. Did I mention it has mods and can co op too?Story with grey morale choices, laced with unique character and NPC voice acting, with turn-based battles that rivals 1861's civil war and story character development of NSA's neighbourhood watch. It's good, really good, especially when it cumulatively rewards you for consistency between choices and planning, for both combat and story dialogue. Quests offers freedom, as in, if an eagle somehow, finds a way to progress through an area, and kill the boss for you, they count it as legit. While it still gives hints, and suggests ways for you to progress, there’s often more than one way to solve a puzzle to complete a quest. The mechanic allows for unique interactions with a pokeball portal device called a pyramid, where you can throw a pyramid through a crack in a window, port in, loot, toss it back, port and bail, while killing every major story NPC and still getting away with it.Seriously it's awesome.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												This is a great game, one of the great RPGs of all time. I've been playing about 120 hours, so I guess that says a ittle in itself about how much I like the game. So here is my review:First of all, I don't like Isometric view in a game, I actually hate it. But for this game with it's turn based combat, it works ok. It is by far the best of this type game ever released. Baldurs Gate, Planescape Torment and all of those older games all suck so bad that for me, they are unplayable. So I was pleasantly surprised when I took a chance on the game and it turned out to be so good. The most negative thing about the game is the camera. That has been improved a lot. I bought the game on the first day of release and the camera annoyed me to the point that I wasn't too sure I could keep playing. But I did and the camera control has got much better and I'm also a lot more used to it now..The best thing about the game is the turned based combat, it's fantastic. The imporatnance of strategy and tactical approach to the combat is very important. A lot of times, you will find yourself in a situation where you are out numbered and the enemies are all higher level than you. But if your strategy and tactical skill is good enough, you can win. You get in situations where you have to really fight smart. This is very rewarding and what makes this game exceptional.The game is also deep. The quests and storyline are deep and many of the quests are very twisted and will surprise you. Character building is also very deep and it might be a little too much for a gamer who doesn't really love RPGs, but if you do love RPGs, you will like this aspect of the game also.I have heard a lot of people say bad things about the graphics in this game. I think they are quite pleasant myself, especially for how huge this game is. Overall I would have to rate the game like this:Story/Quests: 7Graphics: 6Camera Control: 5Soundtrack: 8Combat: 10Great game, I highly recommend it for anyone who loves RPGs and turned based combat.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												"It's over... It's FINALLY over." After drudging through DOS's heavily padded campaign, unlocking the "real" final, final boss, and beating it after a crash on Turn 30, this was all I could think. Divinity: Original Sin starts out beautifully by dropping you off in a large seaport town called Cyseal, the start of your murder mystery. The first dozen or so hours are gripping; not because the plot is particularly good, but because Cyseal feels like a handcrafted cRPG town of old, a gigantic playground for your heroes to explore. However, even within this first area, the game's problems start to rear their ugly heads.The Journal system is almost useless. Quests are just dumped into your book with no filtering or sorting options besides being able to toggle visibility of completed quests. Two very important quests (one was required to continue the story and and another to unlock the "real" final boss fight) were lost in the list of tedious & ambiguous side quests that I picked up along the way. The Journal is also wildly inconsistent with how quests are followed and marked: some quests will drop markers for each part on your map, while others are so vague they will have one line of text saying "congrats! you did it!" with no indication of how to continue the quest. Too many times I had to go to Google just to figure out where I was supposed to go for a quest because the journal, local NPCs, and pocket portal friends were clueless or just too vague.The plot, its pacing, and the gameplay's pacing are all terrible. Many parts of the game involve listening to long-winded NPCs tell you their life story so you can pick up a side quest from them that will simply unlock their store front (or something similarly unimportant). D:OS is overly compartmentalized; you can feel the devs saying "Okay, combat NOW! Okay, 5 hours of NPC chat NOW!" I don't have a problem with reading text in a RPG but D:OS often feels like NPCs are chatting just for the sake of chatting. The story is heavily padded with long, boring sequences that stray from any semblance of plot that the game tries to carry. Too many times I loaded up my saved game and thought "What am I even doing here? Where am I supposed to go? What does this have to do with the story?" The main story itself is godawful too, shoveling in every trope the devs can think of (ancient evils awakening, chosen heroes with amnesia, pandora's box, an evil church, an evil twin sister, etc.) that attempts to twist and turn through a series of often predictable events that your characters have little effect on.  Despite having little voice acting, there are few real dialogue options; most of the time during important NPC conversations, you're sitting there reading page after page of text, pressing 1 repeatedly until you get the chance to press 2 because you have a key item in your inventory from a side quest.Even though the combat system is enjoyable and has plenty of room for character customization, I often found it an exercise in frustration. D:OS's combat isn't hard or even particularly challenging, the game just plays itself better than you do. Enemies often "cheat" by teleporting in more foes after you engage them, a la Dragon Age 2, along with summoning pets of their own. While the Magicka-style elemental combos are a unique touch to a cRPG, enemies often utilize them in unexpected ways, like shooting lightning at a pool of blood (that came out of an enemy you killed) to stun your hero for at least 2-3 rounds (not counting additional stun checks while the field is active). Combat often comes down to who can CC who harder, turning fights into a knockdown/blind/stun-fest while you beat the punching bag enemies before they can summon pets or kill your mages in one enemy's turn. At least a third of the spells in the game have direct upgrades making many early spells obsolete in 20 or so hours (why use a single target version of a spell when the AoE has the same AP cost?). This would be reasonable in a MMO but in a single player cRPG where the highest spell req is level 20, it just looks like lazy design. Like the plot, combat is too compartmentalized; many areas have large swaths of nothing, while the last map in the game has a party of 4-8 mobs every screen width.Tons of smaller issues plague this game. A clunky inventory system where important quest items gets easily lost in a sea of crafting materials. A frustrating crafting system that rewards guesswork and wiki-reading more than ingame exploration. A tedious Rock-Paper-Scissors minigame system for winning dialogue checks. A painfully long mandatory stealth sequence against invincible enemies that will kill your heroes in 2-3 hits. Although I think Divinity: Original Sin is a decent cRPG and I recommend it to fans of the genre, I feel no desire to ever play it again. Too much of D:OS is just tedious busywork in a predictable story that is stretched too thin to be consistently enjoyable.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												Take one of the older Black Isle Studio games, mix in modern tabletop gaming wisdom, the tiniest dash of JRPG charm, a little bit of Ultima's morality (and furniture moving), and stick a co-op cherry on top. Divinity is an absolute blast of an RPG that gets just about everything perfectly right.You are able to tailor each one of your characters into a specific role, and the possibilities are highly varied. Templates are offered to help get you started if you like. Anything from front-line tank, to mobile assassin, to a wizard that manipulates and shuts down the environment and uses his pets for the wetwork, to a support character that crafts the party wicked new equipment, or who enhances the treasures they already own, but there's no reason you can't treat it as a buffet and pick up a little bit of everything. Customization goes beyond the normal STR/DEX/INT stats into independent skills you can level up, abilities you can learn, and (most fun of all) fallout-style perks. Character customization doesn't stop there. There are multiple opportunities to engage in dialog with other NPCs, or even your friend/party if you are playing co-op. Your answers here define your personality traits. Reflect carefully upon them, for you are called upon in certain situations to roleplay your character consistently with previous choices!Combat is highly tactical and turn based. I started out as an air wizard, but later found that pincushioning baddies in the back was a lot more fun for me. Those magic points weren't wasted, as they translated into excellent crowd control abilities. Charm one monster, teleport another away, then stab a third in the back. Wonderful. The power player is amply rewarded, while still allowing you the freedom to make some happy mistakes in customizing your character. Especially in the first quarter of the game, there were a few fights that we bullheadedly jumped into despite being far out of our EXP league, but we would boobytrap the entire environment, move tables and chairs around to create killing zones, and set up devastating openers and were able to squeak by. In the last quarter of the game, our min/maxed characters were so overwhelming that if we were able to get enough of an opening and get all our buffs & debuffs in line, there were very few monsters (boss or otherwise) that we couldn't take out in a single volley. This was our reward for playing so aggressively. That is not to say that combat ever became trivial or tedious, despite being a combat oriented RPG, it is amazing how memorable each and every fight was. There was always some situation that was slightly new, that required us to think a little bit differently. I don't know how they pulled it off, but the results are amazing.I had hesitations playing an RPG game as CO-OP, but those reservations were muted almost immediately. Our very first encounter in the game resulted in us having a disagreement about how to proceed. We resolved that dispute using a mini-game, but each of our characters choices was still reflected in our personality matrix that was being built, so no one feels like they're being bulldozed or wasting their time. “Your objection has been noted in the logs”. Having a friend who specializes and is familiar with their specific character during combat is also a relief - everyone knows their job and how to perform it best.The perfection of Divinity is what leads its rough patches to stand out in even starker detail. Keeping the storyline straight in single player might be hard enough, but in co-op at points it became very difficult.  There is a chat log that records all conversations, yours or otherwise, so this is more of a user interface issue. The writing is good, but not as good as, well, Planescape (That is perhaps unfair). Also some of the "puzzle dungeons" are more obnoxious than they needed to be. Characters don’t really seem to respond differently based on your personality matrix or reputation. Finally, in a single player game, if one of your characters maximizes a skill, say loremaster, then it's something that easily applies to your 3 companions. But in co-op, you have to keep asking your buddy to identify some equipment for you, or remind you what a monster's HP or immunities/weaknesses are. Stuff like that should probably just apply to the entire party with the value being the max of whomever is the highest. There are also a few quest glitches.  Larian seems to be releasing patches often and regularly, so maybe these issues will be buffed out by the time you play. And if you like RPGs, then let's assume that whether you will play this or not is a foregone answer.Final rating: 4.5/5 stars

												Boy oh boy, is it something special to see a game of this type to actually come out in this day and age. With it's mechanics closely tied to Baldur's Gates games, some people are jokingly call it a third installment in the series, but with a few twists. You see, this game is designed from the get-go to be played in coop with your buddy, hence this cool dual dialogue feature and ability for your characters to argue which way you want to act when facing a choice. And it really doesn't work that well when you're playing alone (you have to argue with yourself. wat), so make sure to find someone willing to sunk around 80 to 100+ hours into this game with you.The plot and universe are a bit wishy washy, but it makes up for it with humour, ridiculous situations and some bizzare stories, it this is your sort of thing. Nothing epic like the LOTR trilogy, but you'll get to choose between keeping a herd of imps in your basement or sacrifice them to demons,  which is always fun.Overall it's a solid recommendation if you like crpgs, being one of the best games to come out of Kickstarter and getting top places on charts of 2014.

												Town Simulator 2014 is one of the best games I've played all year. I've only dumped about 13 hours into the game as of this writing, but I can already tell you that what's in store for me is sure to make me appreciate the intricacies and depth of this game even more. Welcome to Cyseal, the busiest, most involved town you'll ever see in a video game. Spend dozens of hours simply walking around, bartering, talking to NPCs, Teleporting party members, digging up graves, stealing paintings, talking to ghosts, picking locks, traveling through time, traveling back to the present, figuring out how to craft, looking online for recipes when you get tired of trying to figure it out, finally crafting, questing, realizing the enemies outside of town are way too hard, going back into town, and much, much more!10/10, will continue to spend hours walking around town and loving every second of it.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Hands down one of the best RPG games I have played in a very long time. It has great depth, great dialog, and great combat. Aside from that the game looks gorgeous and the voice acting is good quality too. I found myself wanting to talk to the npc’s just to find out more about them. The enemies start as mundane run of the mill RPG foes however as you progress the enemies (Without spoiling) become amazing, for example the wee bomb skeletons in the trailer with the huge comical eyes, and matching matchstick. This game has so much customization you end up wanting to start again just to try other ability builds. Then you have the companions, currently there are four in the game but they are slowly converting to 44 henchmen they have into companions. You can have two main characters and they can have a henchman/companion. Companions are just henchmen with story aspects and you’re able to level/gear them just like your main characters.This game really is fantastic and worth every penny.The only con so far is sometimes while chatting in multiplayer pressing R will rotate your action bars, I’m assuming that will be patched as they regularly update the game.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												There are a lot of shennanigans you can do in the game. You can distract NPCs with one of your characters talking to it (you know, keeping an open dialog box) while with the other you steals everything that's not nailed down right in front of it's nose. You can open locked chests with your sword, that is, breaking the container and getting the contents. Heck, you can just grab the chest, locked and all, and carry it home with you.During the development, it was described stuff like, for example, if you need an item from an NPC, you can do it's quest, you can charm the NPC into giving it to you, or you can pickpocket the NPC or, if it's not on him, loot it's house, or you can level the city down and find the item in the rubris. You can subvert the game and it will just play along.How much that's true I don't know, since I'm yet to finish the game, but the game is pretty good at letting you do whatever you want. And that's why it's being that popular.If that wasn't enough, the game is very funny and everyone is voiced over, including enemies. Hearing a skeleton complaining that the other dropped oil on the floor and the other blaming it's arthritis for the accident is quite fun. You'll probably be laughing even before, when you're sneaking on them Metal Gear style to ignite the oil slick.This is a true RPG, where you can RP the ♥♥♥♥ out of the G. Buy it if you didn't yet, because it's awesome.

Unlike console players, PC players know how to read and you will need to do a lot of it. And use your braind to figure things out. Do yourself a favor and BUY THIS GAME.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Being a veteran player who fell in love with Divine Divinity, enjoyed Beyond Divinity, and felt Divinity II fell a little flat - Divinity: Original Sin is refreshing and hella' lotsa' fun!TL;DR - Brilliant game - Worth your money and time - Easily justifies the £30 price tag, with me currently standing at 50+ hours, still not finished, and with a reasnable amount of replayability.The game feels like it should, large open world (Albeit with 4 medium sized seperate instanced areas), which holds surprises and secrets for those that search it all. As it should.Controls are mouse control driven, and fairly easy to get the hang of. Combat is a little different to the live action style of DIvine and Beyond. Instead we have a turn based combat system. This put me off at first, but what it allows is a more tactical style of fighting. Trying to organise your steam clouds location, and well placed lightning bolt to charge the cloud would be impossibly chaotic in real time. The system can get a little sluggish when in large encounters, with the enemy AI taking large amounts of time to take its turns. However as long as you can dispatch enemy combatents quickly, the time they take quickly decreases. A live action combat style in Divnity Sin would feel a little out of place. However, perhaps a mod, or patch can create this functionality (If the engine can even support it) optionally.The game doesnt take itself too seriously, again as it should, with jokes and quirky quests around every corner. Loot is interesting and randomised. At times the pools of different cosmetics for the armor can be a little spares, but I imagine more unique skins will be added as time goes on. Unique items are interested, powerfull, and rare enough not to feel too easy to gain. Companions can be customised as much as the two main charecters, and hold there own interesting stories, and quirky comments as the adventure goes on.I havent had a chance to play CO-OP which I imagine will sell the game to a lot of people, the drop in drop out multiplayer seems easy enough to manage, and with party decisions having to be voted in, could lead to some very interesting gameplay. However lossing control of one charecter, may make combat that little bit more labourious.Sunk over 50 hours into this £30 game - £1 = 1 Hour rule easily acheived - In that regard, totally worth your money and time, for both veteran players looking for Divine nostalgia, or new players look for an interesting fantasy RPG with its own quirks and flare.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I've been playing Divinity: Original Sin for some time now and what a joy its been. Anyone familiar with the other Divinity titles truly must purchase this little gem (and yes, it's worth the full price). If you're more familar with games like Baldur's Gate then likewise, you'll feel right at home here. If I were to compare the two then I have to say D:OS wins hands down. The turn based combat is fun and challenging, particularly in boss fights, and the game has lots of humour strewn throughout (Weresheep anyone?). The quests are completely non-linear, which can be as rewarding as they are annoying at times. Being so non-linear you're often left with very little information and if not completed in the right order then you can end up botching a mission without even realizing it. Some of the puzzles are ridiculously complex, so if a challenge is what you want then look no further. I've literally spent hours looking for hidden passages and switches!  Overall a very solid RPG and with the modding community involved and the games level designer, I can see this game living on for many years to come. Add to this the fact that Multi-Player is so much fun, and all in all this game is a winner.Highly recommended for traditional RPG players and Strategy fans out there. I must leave you now. I have to go and hook up my Cat friend Unsinkable Sam with some P-U-S-S-Y. ;)

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												This is an old-school cRPG done right which is such a rarity these days. If you, like me, spent hours/days playing Fallout series, Baldur's Gate 1-2. Icewind Dale 1-2, Planescape: Torment and such (regardless if you finished them or not :) you will most likely love this one too. Divinity: Original Sin succeeds greatly at almost every aspect of old-school RPG: intriguing plot with plenty of quests to complete and many interesting characters to interact with; beautiful, "warm" graphics with colorful special effects; music and soundtrack, creating mood for adventure and exploration; battle system which can quite challenging. I particularly like the elements system in magic and how one can use nature elements for one's advantage against the enemies. And how the same nature elements can instantly paralyze/freeze/burn/shock/poison/debilitate/kill your character if they are used improperly.I guess the only thing that I didn't like or found inconveniet was loot/inventory system. It is cluttered and can be a really pain in the butt, lots of times your characters end up with tons of useless junk or used items that are real chore to trade/sell. Then again, constantly searching for new equipment or spending hours comparing different swords/bows/armor/pants can be very entertaining. :). Well done, Larian.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												What a fabulous game. I can't believe how long I played it. As a lover of the old D&D gold box games (e.g. Pools of Radiance, Curse of the Azure Bonds, Death Knights of Krynn, etc) it's amazing what Larian has done here. I thought I would never see a deep, long, turn based and tactical rpg again, but here it is. What a pleasent surprise.Pros:+ long, deep+ turn based combat that works well+ great spells and environmental affects+ good story (if a bit silly sometimes)+ beautiful graphics+ smooth, bug free gameplay+ great rpg elements beyond the combat (eg great spells, leveling, classess, abilities, etc)+ doesn't hold your hand, its a thinking man's game. It's hard, and you will die a lot, especially early on.+ great quest system+ great co-op systemCons: (there are really only a few)- inventory system can be a little tough to manage.- late game/end game spells feel a little weak for their costOverall, this is a phenomenal game for any old school rpg lover, well worth your dollars. You will get sucked into this, for a long time, and love every minute of it.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												The best turn based CRPG i have ever played.The mechanics are designed in a way that is truly open world. Character creation is meaty and every character you make feel unique and your own. Leveling is very rewarding and the synergy you can build across your 4 characters is endless. The gameplay respects the players intelligence. No fluff or hand holding and this is the most rewarding part of the game. you play the game how you want, break down which doors you would like to enter and play quests in the order you see fit. UI and graphics are clean and do their job of giving all the information about damage/status/etc. Coop is restricted to 2 people, which i think is the perfect amount for this game. skype + this game is amazingBeen meaning to write this quick review for a while. It has to be my game of the year, i cant think of any glaring flaws.9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Having just finished my first playthrough, I have to say that I'm ashamed that I didn't pick this game up earlier.  It's an utter masterpiece in the CRPG genre, bringing back very fond memories of the Baldur's Gate series, Fallout series, and even a little of PlaneScape: Torment.  If you're a fan of any of those games, do yourself a favor and pick this game up, especially if it's on sale.The combat is great, and the classes/abilities are excellent, but the true gem of this game is the story.  There are plenty of side quests packed into the environments if you look for them, and none of them feel cheap or thrown in.  Each contributes in its own way to the main story, with a few that span multiple arcs and were so well done that I wasn't sure which was the main story quest at some points.The only real complaints I have about the game were related to weapons breaking very quickly (especially for rogue characters), and some design issues related to the last boss (he will auto-target and kill a crucial NPC in the first round of combat if you don't set the fight up correctly).  Other than those two minor gripes, the game is a sparkling gem in a sea of absolutely horrible RPGs.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Very few games in a decade have an original personality to them.  Divinity: Original Sin does.  It has humor, puzzles, and complex features that are not seen so artfully done in other games.  Also, for those who have played Dvinity: Dragon Knight Saga, this game is nothing like that.  But that's pretty obvious for anyone who has played any measure of western RPGs.So, okay, what's great about it?  The art style, the atmosphere, the music, the idle banter with townsfolk, and the dungeons.  And the quests.  Let's compare this to another game that came out recently.  Dragon Age: Inquisition.  DAI has what could be considered MMO-caliber quests in a single-player existence.  D:OS goes the other way, making each quest interactive, unique, and enjoyable.  And no, the game is not easy.  Was Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale easy?  No.  Were Divine Divinity and Beyond Divinity easy?  No.  So why should you expect this one to be any different.  Dragon Age Inquisition could be seen as easy, with a side of complexity.  Divinity: Original Sin is complex, difficult, and utterly without regret about that point.  It's not Dark Souls 1 or 2, obviously, but it's still pretty difficult.A game being difficult isn't inherently bad, but it will turn off some players who are afraid to fail.  You will fail in D:OS.  Simply making characters in the beginning is an involved process that can cause you enormous amounts of trouble throughout the game.  I had the ill fortune of my first two characters being made in the exact image of the first (and at the time, only) voiced companions.  So my warrior and mage were entirely the same as the warrior and mage that joined my party.  In say....World of Warcraft, five moonkin druids in an arena match have a change to starfire an enemy to death.  It might work.  But in Divinity, having characters with the same spells and abilities is just...crippling.The game revolves around a complex and interstellar story that weaves the four great elements together with much finesse.  Fire, ice/water, air,  poison/earth.  There are variations to each element, and each one cancels out another.  Having a party that can effectively control all four elements will make life soooooo much easier for everyone involved.  There are puzzles everywhere, and dungeons require cunning and manipulation of these elements.  If you like JRPGs or Bioware RPGs, you may not like this game.  It has everything that an avid Role Playing Game enthusiest would love, but it's just not built in a way that casual gamers would enjoy.  I mention JRPGs because they're built in an entirely different way.  Sure, they're both turn-based, but JRPGs represent items, damage, and instant encounters so much differently.In D:OS there ARE NO RANDOM ENCOUNTERS.  You fight the enemies that exist in the world, and once you do, they're dead.  No grinding.  No wasting time.  To compensation for this, each enemy has its own particular brand of evil to employ.  And it's all trial and error.  Sure, you may win a battle against some orcs, but I guarantee to you that the next band of orcs will be entirely different.  They will employ shamans and rogues and all manner of foul magics to make your life hell.Dvinity: Original Sin is one of the most interesting games I've played, yet it's not something I can play repeatedly.  It's not a Skyrim/Oblivion/Morrowind or a Dragon Age Origion/2/Inquisition.  This game requires you to think.  And when you think, you will succeed.  And when you succeed, you will feel good about it.  That's it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												An RPG that reminds you of the older RPGs where you were not handheld and not all enemies were dead in a few strikes.Divinity: Original Sin is a game where you are given the basics of how the game works and you need to figure out the rest while going in your adventure. Many choices you make actually change the world around you and the the way the NPCs regard you. But what is the game about? Well, you play as a source hunter called, along with another source hunter, to solve a mystery and uncover even greater mysteries that lead you on a quest to save the world. There are 2 main characters, so you can co-op with a friend, or, if you want, play solo like myself as you are not punished for that. You also get 4 unique companions which have their own personalities and stories though you can have at most 2 come with you, one for each main character (you can have even less if you use a special talent that boosts your power but the character can't have a follower, but I wouldn't recommend it, if nothing else, at least for the comments your companions make). If you don't like the unique companions you can get random mercenary companions a bit later. Now, the world itself is quite big and there is no handholding so you need to figure out some things on your own. While the world itself is real time, the battles are turn based, each of your characters and enemies acting in a queue according to how many action points they posess (this can be changed through stats).One thing to keep in mind is that this is a game where you need to be attentive everywhere as there can be hidden treasures everywhere (and if not, worthless items to sell at least) or traps that can instant-kill some of your party members. You can sneak to have surprise attacks, you can pickpocket npcs and sometimes you have this rock-paper-scissors games to convince others that your point is the right one(you can skip it if you dislike it).The game provides interesting challenges and puzzles (like knowing what item goes where, what spell you can use to unlock an item or destroy it etc) which could be challenging to some but that you can even skip if you read all books and papers you encounter as the rules are sometimes explained there. Or, alternatively, you can try to use brute force! You want what's in the chest but don't want to guess how to go through the lava to the key? Smash it with a club and get the contents! Or use your lockpicking to open it instead. Use magic to open it. In general the game gives you multiple choices for different problems you may encounter.As for battles, enemies are non-respawning, so each you kill brings you closer to the end, and each encounter is unique, some group may use poison then set everything on fire, while another will appeal only to brute force. Sometimes the enemy tries to use tanky characters, sometimes they send 20 bomb bots at you. Each battle is unique, and this makes some harded and some easier depening on your preffered playstyle, it makes you organize and think of the best way. Save often though, you will need it.That being said, you need to remember, this is a long story, and there will be lots to read. You will sit reading stuff for a long, long time and you better remember the things as... well, no handholding, so not everything is remembered in your quest log.Graphics - 9.5/10 - really good graphics yet you can see in general the limitations of what they did (for example you can't rotate the map 360%, I belive the rotating angle is more around 90% so you may have problems talking to rats hiding under rocks.Audio - 9/10 - Awesome music, most NPCs have flavour text that is both written and audio and in general really simulates the town and other area life quite well. Gameplay - 9.5/10 - As I said, much reading, turn based battle system but open world exploration, quite a few talents, attributes, companions etc.There are however some negative aspects as well:1. You need a mage-type character - doesn't matter if it's a companion or main hero(you find companions early on) but you really need a mage as you can't pass some puzzles without the skills that a mage employs.2. The crafting system is a bit weird. To give you an example, you want to craft a belt, you need 4 wool which you split in 2 stacks of 2, combine them and make 2 yarn, split them, combine them and make a rope. You then get a sharp claw, you get some star flowers which you grind to make stardust, you take a skull or a bone, you grind and make bonedust, You combine the dusts to make 1 pixie dust. You combine pixie dust with claw and make a magical claw. You combine magical claw with rope and you have a lovely +1 strengh belt... a bit dismantling to say the least. Well, this is quite realistic, yet also quite time-consuming and makes you feel like you haven't achieved much. Not all combinations are clear (you can combine a glass of milk with a jar of honey, a bucket of water with flour, yet not a bucket of milk with a jar of honey for whatever reason) so you may need guides on net on how you craft most things.3. Crafting is not very useful. Sure, you can make potions, that's awesome... but the gear you make is not very good compared to gear you find. In general, the gear you make is common but with some stats and while it can be good if you have no item at all equipped or haven't found an item for that slot for 5+ levels (if this happens, you haven't visisted vendors enough), in general those items are only good for one thing, and that is selling them.4. The rock-paper-scissors system can be annoying at times, thankfully it is skippable.Overall though I will say this game is amazing. While it has its issues, these seem to pale in the light of the general feel of the world, the way the mechanics work, the story and the relation between the characters, the dungeons, puzzles, looks and music and this makes it a must have for any older RPG fan. And remember, there won't be much handholding ;)

Posted: September 12, 2014
												Absolutely awesome game!Very well made, so many tactical options to explore, the coop mode is fantastic and great fun, soundtrack is always fitting and never annoying, some funny and some serious quests.. I could go on for hours!There are just a few very minor things, like in the end we had to look at a guide to find the last 3 stones (we walked past them) and because the game allows stuff like teleporting there are a few bugs you can find if you get creative - but we enjoyed that! It also means you can find alternative ways to solve some of the quests. There is always a way out of an hairy situation although it often feels otherwise..If you are not sure about the genre just play coop, there is a lot of interaction between the players so there is always something going on.I rarely buy games for more than 20 € but this is one of the games that are absolutely worth it!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												I wanted this for the co-op.  I love both RPGs and co-op, and this is a rare blend of the two.  I was expecting a pretty traditional Diablo 2-like experience, but what I've found is closer to the Dungeons and Dragons pencil and paper game.  And I mean that inin the best way.  There is more focus on story and exploration.  You are not just given a list of quests to complete.  Instead you keep track of different story lines and goings on in the world of Divinity.  Sometimes these story lines will draw you into quests or maybe tie into something you learned earlier.  There are plenty of classes and choices to make so that your chracters end up pretty unique.  Playing co-op and having a friend control the other main character is a joy.  It's fun to see the different interactions and the different outcomes from situations.  Seems like it has a lot of replay value, especially given the potential for mods.  I've played about 15  hours sp far and am loving it.  Recommended to D&D fans, RPG fans, and certainly co-op gamers who enjoy the role play genre.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Critics exploded around this game, hailing it a return to the old school RPG. Is it that? Yes. But not much else. The graphics are modern, but the gameplay and the story are definitely part of the old school. Turn based combat. Elemental spells and skills. Monsters that have access to the same skills you have. I mean, the formula is here from back in the day, man. The story is also pretty classic. But the bottom line: is it fun? I played through the story with a friend. Added an extra layer to it. I recommend doing that. They fixed some of the co-op bugs, although we enjoyed reading to each other as if we were tucking the other in for the night. We're that close of friends. Buy and play it with your blood brother. A/5

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												note - I have played this game 42 more hours than will be listed, due to having played it on a non-steam version prior to purchasing it on steam. I am still playing it now. At least 75 hours of serious gameplay, sticking only to the main story and working with a background in rpgs (i.e. kind of rapidly through it.) note note ! - the combat is the best I have ever experienced. (in a game. Lol! the streets is were I born.)An excellent RPG. pros - turn-based combat. Button-smashing (proc sequences, Wow/guild wars gamers you know what I'm talking about) repetitive, often only marginally conditionally dynamic patterns onto the numbers of your keyboard - this game removes that need. The walking-on-eggshells feeling of always swapping between auto-run and strafing keys (q, e in guild wars/wow) to approach fights while still having fingers keyed up to smash into those damaging sequences of abilities/spells is gone.  pro - strategic turn-based combat - accomplishment is real. The system of this game is intuitive, optimizing your use of it to have your characters triumph over enemies is intellectually rewarding.pro - dynamic strategic turn-based combat- Fighting a single boss from fighting enemies outnumbering oneselves twenty - to - five, and the continuous and surprising scaling between these extremes lead to gameplay that is as different as playing two separate games. The development of conditional strategies has far more depth than the "mute or hamstring," single button interchanges that more basic rpgs offer (again, wow is alluded to.)pro - customization- Diablo 2 style character building. You may have two characters, or four, or in the well-implemented co-op, only one. This hinges upon using lone-wolf or not, a feat (think DnD, any edition) that can channel a balanced but complete amount of ability/attribution/stats that is by default spread across two characters into a single character. The development planning may be either serious or casual, depending on how you like your gaming. Challenging on standard difficulty. Excellent, very customizable spell building.pro - the feeling that any time not spent developing/optimizing characters may be spent developing/optimizing strategy instead, leading to, ultimately, similar feelings of gleeful, smart glory.pro - modular/randomly generated loot. This is what it's all about, homies.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												I could sit here and write a thousand words as to why this game is worth every penny, and why you shouldn't think twice about buying this game. But since the professional reviewers have already done an amazing job at detailing what makes this game so special, I'll just keep it simple: Get. This. Game!There's easily a 100 hours worth of content in this game. The turn-based combat system works wonderfully well. The game is challenging enough to keep you on your toes. And there's even some multiplayer if you want to go at it with a friend. Larian did an amazing job with this game and I certainly can't wait for the next installment. Highly recommend!

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Divinity Original Sin is truly a shining diamond, a master-class in Old-School Top-Down RPG's. Taking inspiration from the likes of Baldur's Gate, D:OS shows that it isn't afraid to slap you in the face, kick you in the balls, cut you to pieces and make you get back up again for Round 2. It doesn't hold you're hand, it doesn't help you virtually at all... The tools are right in front of you, Divinity just expects you to learn and know how to use them, yourself.The art-design is striking and gorgeous. The turn-based combat is rock-solid with great mechanics backing it. The story is great though I'll admit it could be a little better. The gameplay aside from the combat with the rock-paper scissors mini-games to accidentally starting a fight with a merchant when you misclick and throw a candle-stick at him lighting him on fire is just brilliant. I've never played an RPG as good as this one and I've played alot.Call me a fanboy or whatever you want, but Divinity : Original Sin is one of those true gems, and a stellar masterpiece that roared out of its KickStarter funding. Thank you Larian for giving me an experience of a lifeitme.10/10. Buy if you want your world and view on RPG's to be blown away. LOVE IT!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												For me, the best RPG since Knights of the Old Republic and Dragon Age: Origins. I just finished it reaching about level 22.5 with my gang of Two-Handed-Warrior, Pyro/Geomancer with a bit witchcraft, rogue and Hydromancer/Aerotheurge. On second replay, I'd take a party consisting of one Two-Handed-Warrior, one rogue, one ranger and one witchy/hydromancing mage, that should work like a breeze.There is lots and lots of good to tell about this (for example the turn-based combat works perfectly and is very funny without being frustrating... the character development might not be the most complex of all RPGs but is very much enough for me), but there are also some minor things that should be tweaked via patch, for example that most of the items you find are strength-based and as such only usable on warriors... that magic starts strong but get outclassed by bow and melee damage after about character level 10... that the first 7 or so levels are slow because you just don't get enough skill points per level for my taste (you begin with one per level, later two, later three. You should start at two imo).To sum it all up: nearly a must-have for every RPG fan.

I've never played an RPG as good as this one and I've played alot.Call me a fanboy or whatever you want, but Divinity : Original Sin is one of those true gems, and a stellar masterpiece that roared out of its KickStarter funding. Thank you Larian for giving me an experience of a lifeitme.10/10. Buy if you want your world and view on RPG's to be blown away. LOVE IT!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												For me, the best RPG since Knights of the Old Republic and Dragon Age: Origins. I just finished it reaching about level 22.5 with my gang of Two-Handed-Warrior, Pyro/Geomancer with a bit witchcraft, rogue and Hydromancer/Aerotheurge. On second replay, I'd take a party consisting of one Two-Handed-Warrior, one rogue, one ranger and one witchy/hydromancing mage, that should work like a breeze.There is lots and lots of good to tell about this (for example the turn-based combat works perfectly and is very funny without being frustrating... the character development might not be the most complex of all RPGs but is very much enough for me), but there are also some minor things that should be tweaked via patch, for example that most of the items you find are strength-based and as such only usable on warriors... that magic starts strong but get outclassed by bow and melee damage after about character level 10... that the first 7 or so levels are slow because you just don't get enough skill points per level for my taste (you begin with one per level, later two, later three. You should start at two imo).To sum it all up: nearly a must-have for every RPG fan.
