number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												If you are an avid RPG player, if you prefer figuring stuff out by yourself and not relying on a marker telling you where to go like most games in the market lately, if you want to actually use your head when playing games. BUY THIS GAME.The story is interesting enough to keep you going through till the end. Though I cannot say for sure about the rest of the games, because 18 hours in and I still haven't finished map 1. And this game has 4 maps with same size and 6 smaller maps. It will easily net you a 100 hours of entertainment.The gameplay and the complexity of actually role playing in this game is top notch. An enemy has multiple ways to be approached, a quest has multiple ways to be solved, a situation has different methods to tackle.The interactivity between you and the environment, the multiple solutions for any obstable is the strongest point of this game.Let me give you an example, to cross a slippery icy surface, you can either upgrade your shoes with nails, use fire to melt the ice, or teleport yourself over the surface. Keep in mind that this is just a simple thing, many more advanced and interesting concept is open for you to discover.Buy this game. Have patience. Reaping the reward that is the satisfaction that a game treats you like an intelligent wizard and not a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ baby that needs to be told to press space to jump over obstacles.BUY IT.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Recommended, but not for 40 euros.+  120 hours to casually work my way through the entire story and nearly all of the side-quests.+  Tons of magic and combat skills to choose from, with nothing tied to any particular "class".  Build whatever character you like.+  Story was fun and funny at times, sad and dark at others.  I enjoyed most of the voice characterizations.+  A ton of inventory.+  2-player co-op, easily modded to a workable 4-player co-op.+  Workshop-  A ton of inventory, with a pretty horrible set of options for dealing with it.  You can sort your main inventory by weight, by gold value, etc., but you can't do the same with your backpack.  Whatever you stuff in there stays in the slot it lands in forever, unless you drag it to a new slot.  There's no option to sort backpacks at all, and since there was sooo much stuff to deal with I'd naturally split it up into various backpacks pretty early on.  I had a food backpack, a crafting ingredients backpack, and so on, but by the end of the game it was so tedious to deal with it all or find anything that I often didn't bother.-  Which leads to negative #2:  A ton of food, which I barely ate.  I'd be surprised if I ate something half a dozen times throughout the entire game.  Food just wasn't a necessity at all, and was actually pretty much a liability in terms of weight.  Between spells and potions there was no need to eat anything during combat, ever, and since a healing spell outside of combat is free to use there was no reason to eat food outside combat, either.  I ended the game with a massive sack full of pies and juices and assorted goodies, feeling almost like I'd done something wrong by not eating it all.-  A few broken/bug-prone areas.  Twice I experienced a bug where a character's weapons and/or armor would disappear, during combat.  Despite being able to easily repeat the bug in both locations, and sending in a report, Support says they couldn't duplicate it, so no help there.  All I can say is save very often, and get in the habit of checking each character's inventory often.  It makes everything more tedious, but I guess it's better than realizing too late that some precious bow has been gone for who knows how long.The game's a ton of fun, but the 40 euro price is a bit steep for something with a pretty clunky way of dealing with the huge amount of stuff you'll be dealing with, and a few potentially game-breaking bugs like disappearing weapons that are still occuring, years after development started.  And the extra 8 euros for the "collectors edition" is a crime for what's included.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												This is not the RPG savior some make it out to be, but it's still a very nice game. It's fun to play, but some of the flaws can make it tedious at times. Overall much better than most of the RPGs of recent years.The rules system is a little simplistic, but workable. It's classless, which is a plus in my books. The "starting classes" are more like examples or templates, which you can edit freely. They mainly determine your starting equipment. There is no level bloat. I got to level 21 in my 95 hour playthrough, which is reasonable. There is some HP and damage bloat. Those numbers swell quite a lot over the course of the game.One of my biggest beefs with the game are the loot avalanche and the gear stats system. The gear a is very ARPGish collection of numbers and percentages. It is supposed to make as much as possible of it unique, but ends up making nothing feel special, and I still got a few identical amulets of air resistance at one point. Most of the gear has stat limits, which I don't mind when they make sense. It sounds reasonable that you need to be strong enough to swing that big sword or wear that heavy armor, or be intelligent enough to cast that spell or unleash the mystical energies of that staff. I can even buy that you need certain amount of dexterity for a bow, but why on earth would you need dexterity to wear a leather armor? Are the buckles that tricky? Intelligence to wear a sarong? Is it that hard to figure out? I can understand that they did this to force the characters to specialize, but surely there could have been a better approach to this. Weapons also have levels, which I think is pretty silly. If you are on lower level than the weapon, you have to spend extra AP to use it. Equipment also has a durability stat and may need to be repaired occasionally. I think that's pretty pointless mechanic for this game. At least most of the stuff tends to get obsolete so fast you don't have to worry about repairing much.The loot avalanche is part of the gear situation. You tend to get a lot of loot and thanks to the ARPGish item stat and level system, much of it can't be dismissed to "just sell it" pile at a glance, but makes you want to compare it with all of your characters' current gear just to be sure. This gets tedious. Maybe I'm just a bit of OCD. I learned to not care so much later on and only really payed attention to "Legendaries" that tend to stay effective at least few levels past their initial level, especially if you use crafting to improve them. You also get a lot of crafting components as loot, but with the crafting system being just rubbing items with each other in the inventory, or sometimes rubbing them with crafting objects in the world, I quickly lost interest with most of it. Just occasionally improved my swords and armor. A some kind of interface would have been nice there. At least you can sell stuff to pretty much any character who has something to trade for it, much like in Fallouts. In my case this lead to the curious habit of trying to trade with everyone as conversation opens in case they turn hostile later.The combat is great. There is enviromental interactivity in it that reminds me of Dragon Age: Origins, but much richer and overall better because it's turn based instead of RTwP. There is a lot of depth. The combat never got old for me, though it was a little unwieldy in one huge humans vs orcs battle, but that has always been the downside of TB combat in these games. It doesn't scale to very big battles very well. Still definitely the strongest aspect of this game.The main campaign story is decent. I wish the epic save the world story could have been averted, but I guess it's unavoidable in a long game like this. As I mentioned, it took me 95 hours to finish in my semi-completitionist manner, that is to say, I tried to find everything at first and then got bored and just wanted to finish it. It is somewhat unfocused because of the open world approach. It's not even effectively so open world. There is clearly a certain path you are supposed to follow. If you don't and wander off, you'll run into higher level enemies. These can be defeated, but they will then drop higher level loot you can't use effectively. The journal entries and conversations may also become little messed up when you do complete things in wrong order.Best part of the writing is not in the main story, but the little jokes on the sides. Few of the NPCs make me really care about them. The persuasion system is an odd roshambo game, which I guess makes more sense if you co-op the with somebody. It seems like a lot of attention was put on the co-op, though you can only play with 2 players unless you use a mod.There is also and editor, and in my eyes that will decide if this game will be another DA:O or another NWN: A good game that I will beat once or twice and then forget, or a game that will stay installed for years because of the endless stream of new player made adventures available. The early reports are not promising, but maybe Larian will improve and support it.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												This game was one of the most rewarding and complex "old-school"-RPGs of this year.It took me and my friend 70 hours to finish the main campaign, which is A LOT, I recon. The skill-system is quite nice for such a humongus game and the story is amazingly fascinating.I must bring up one "negative" point regarding the game though. You will HAVE to read the quests! You cannot play it WOW-style since you lack the information to solve several puzzles then.Me and my friend encountered 2 issues who were only mildly disturbing:1. The main quest-line was bugged at some point far at the ending since we missed one part. But that issue recified itself quite quickly.2. STEAM ♥♥♥♥ed up some times and that is entirely not the games fault.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin. An incredible, fun and really well built classic RPG. Everything from the superb story to the wonderful soundtrack and voice acting is very well done. The combat is extremely fun, with the environmental combos bringing a whole new world of fighting on the rpg table. The writing is classic Larian writing, so if you enjoy other Larian games, you'll love this one. It won't hold your hands, you'll have to think, observe, use your witts to complete your adventure. Saving a lot also helps. This game is a must play. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												I was skeptical to spend $40 on a Steam game.  It's been awhile since I've paid more than $10 for anything, and even those I try to get for less if possible.  Was waiting for this to go on sale since January 2014.  It hasn't that I've seen.  You needn't bother waiting.  Dear God I've been waiting for an RPG of this caliber for years.  It's epic.  It's gorgeous.  It's fun.  It's deep.  Soundtrack is awesome, voice acting is awesome.  Fights are HARD.  I feel like I'm playing a combination of Ultima VII and Baldur's Gate II on crack.  I've put 50+ hours in, and my characters are level SIX.  I've seen level 10 spells available.  They tease things out JUST right.  Gold is tight...you really need to 'need' something before you buy it.  Co-Op has been FLAWLESS.  This game is just plain brilliant for any Iso-view RPG fans.  Absolutely AAA top-notch.  Did I mention it's fun to look at also?  You will get your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you until you fully understand the elemental mechanics...finally got that fire ability?  Be careful  =)  But once you get it, DAMN there are some amazing combos available.It is (appears to be anyway) VERY bug free.  In fact, I haven't seen one single major issue yet.  No crashes, no graphics problems, no soft-locks, no file issues, no inventory problems, no spell problems, etc. etc. etc.  One small issue (very small) is a sound (just music) hiccup maybe occassionally, but hardly worth noticing...it's music between areas and there's a very slight stutter.  There are just no big issues of any kind.  I'm playing on a slightly out-dated laptop with general High settings.  It's so good.  100% recommended for RPG fans.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Rediculously fun - if you were a fan of Arcanum, Baldurs Gate (PC versions, not PS2/Xbox), Icewind Dale, etc - you will love it. If you played the recent X-Com, and wanted more *everything* - you'll love it.The characters are memorable overall (yes, NPC's without names can get tedious, but still). Areas are diverse, and battlegrounds are things of tactical enginuity (water spells/arrows are your friend with burning dead).There's so **much** content it's unreal. I wish games like this were more commonplace, and it's great to see that dev's realize that turn based mechanics never went out of fashion in the real world - it's just the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ shareholders who think that you can only sell titles if they are dumbed down and made real-time.Turn based gaming / classic rpg styles like this, ironically are more of a breath of fresh air, and much more replayable, and memorable as well as addictive than any real-time game I've played in quite some time.To Larian studios: Well done sirs, well done.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												As a gamer in his 30's, this game is like striking gold. If you are old enough to remember games like Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape, and all of the other what I call "birds eye view" RPGs, you'll be in heaven. It plays JUST like those older ones, coupled with modern day graphics. It's challenging and rewarding. There is no hand holding, or quest markers on your mini map telling you exactly where to go. You'll have to look for clues in dialogue when interacting with NPCs. You are free to do anything. Want to play as the heroic white knight rescuing Cysael from the evil that plagues it? This game is for you. Want to play a band of rogueish mercenaries paid for your services while simultaneously breaking and entering into peoples homes and cleaning them out? This game is for you. Want to go ham and just slaughter all of the citizens of said town? Go for it, however I wouldn't reccomend that lol. I haven't finished it yet, but I've heard this game boasts 80+ hours of content. Well worth the price. If I met the lead game designer, I would shake his hand.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												If you love(d) old school RPG's like Baulder's Gate, Dungeon Siege, Neverwinter Nights (and the like) this game is a MUST have! Haven't played anything this good in years. You really have to think about the choices and actions you make, as they impact the people you talk to and what opportunities you have available to you. This game definitely doesn't hold your hand.Combat is turn-based (with action points) and strategic, and reminds me a lot of tabletop D&D. I didn't like it at first, but after a while you get use to it, and it's actually pretty cool. There is friendly fire, so placement of your heroes is key! You can use your stronger party members to protect your weaker ones.Some tips before you get into the game: - Save!!! Save before you go through a door, or down into a crypt, or before you engage groups of enemies. It'll save you a lot of headaches.- Holding down ALT shows you all the items sitting on tables/floors. Use this constantly!- Not everything is as it seems. Look for switches on walls, levers, movable crates, dig on top of dirt mounds (save before you do!).- Talk to everyone. They pretty much all have information for you.- Remember, you're not stuck to your quest. If you want to go exploring, feel free to! In fact, that's the best way to find small quests, fun battles, and nice loot.The only problem I have with it so far: the first 4-5 hours or so is pretty slow. But it picks up from there. I really enjoy it. And if you like CRPG's, you'll like this too.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												I am not often writing recommendations, but for this gem I got to. Larian Studios have done a fantastic job in bringing out a game true to the golden age of CRPG. What you get with Divinity Original Sin is a mix of Baldur's Gate and the original Fallout. Attention to detail is fantastic, although the text elements might sometimes get a bit too heavy for some of you. The combat system is dead on right for me, with a good mix of tactical elements, decision making and choices on how to best approach an enemy. The story is deep and you have plenty of well designed side quests to keep you happy four countless hours. I have the habbit of taking it slow and explore every corner of the enviroment and I can tell you, it is a blast exploring in this beautifully crafted world. Divinity gives you various options on how to approach quests or areas and you are not necessarily bound to have specific character classes with you in order to solve or explore specific areas. In most group RPGs I try to have at least one rouge class character with me (although I do not necessarily prefer it), just to be able to open every chest or get into every location. Larian Studios has managed to prvide access to many areas or access to various situations without depending too much on specific character classes. Just to give you one example, I was surprised to find out that after using my rouge to unlock a door to an abandoned house I desperately wanted to get into, I could have broken down the door with a character that had enough strength or, after managing to get in, I saw that there was another secret entrance through a well in the countryside. Allaround a well designed game!

								So up until now with the new fixes and updates on the game it is steadily improving, i like how the game progresses and it is unusualy deep.I personaly think that the combat needs alot more fixing since it happened to me that sometimes a battle that is sure to be won is just hard as hell, also i dont like the experience system in battles since if you do not kill a enemy with your own atack,meaning that if it gets last hittes by an NPC or a status effect like burn or poison ( doesnt matter if you inflicted that status effect yourself) you do not get that experience from the enemy, which is i think really a shame since every fight you have is hard if you do not think about it a little more ( like what spell to use, where to stand etc. ).Now in that case i would find it more suitable to reduce the experience that you get from each enemy kill, but in exchange let the game give you the experience even if the enemy dies by status effect and/or an NPC.To avoid getting less experience if i fail to kill a few enemies is that i quicksave alot and if i encounter a fight and dont get the kills by my own character i reload that save i did and try again. I think that alot of people do that already and in my oppinion it ruins the game experince and it is also ruins multiplayer experince.So far the only big problem i encountered is that one, other than that i like the game very much, the quest system is good but the screen where the quests are displayed needs more polishing, the running around back and forth betwen people and talking to them for quests is not bad in any way since alot of games have backtracking, but i would reduce the backtracking a bit.Also one last thing, i know it still may be early but i would for now like the devs to focus more on opening new areas and places you can go to, than the other minor bug fixes and polishes, since i think that widening the game now would prove more uselfull in the long run because more issues can be seen and fixed quickly before they become a problem.Well for now these are things id like to change, but hey i mean alpha is alpha, no way getting around it but gaining experience and fixing things.All in all i love the game, and i have always loved these kind of games ever since i played the first Dungeon Siege game.Keep on doing just the way you did guys, i really look forward to the finished product.Good Work, good luck and may Goc bless you for making this awesome game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												Hands down by GOTY 2014. Absoultely incredible game design, Original Sin is a world populated with characters, quests and enemies that you will love to explore. The flawless crpg elements are upgraded with squad-based tactical combat that feels very fresh. Weather and your party's control of the elements completely alters your approach to each encounter. Further on the note of combat, I found the balance between my team's ability level and the enemies I was facing very fine-tuned- rush into an area you're not ready for and you will be crushed, but at no point is there any mundane grinding (enemies do not respawn, ever). If you are at all inclined toward RPGs, even if you feel an isometric perspective is dated (which it is), you owe it to yourself to give Divinity:OS a shot.

												Playing Divinity: Original Sin reminds me a lot of my time spent playing Ultima VII: The Black Gate (arguably the best of the Ultima series in my honest opinion) back in my highschool days.  Original Sin is one of those games that is so open it can leave players scratching their heads as their imaginations run wild as to do next.  This game is DEEP!Oh yeah... number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Update 8/23/2014:The game-breaking (for our build) bug introduced in the last patch have been removed by a hotfix a day later, thanks to Larian for that. I still recommend NOT buying this (or any game) on Steam if it's available elsewhere where you the user can control when/if the game updates (in this case GoG allows you to do that with D:OS).Update 8/22/2014:Do not buy this game on Steam, get it from GoG. Steam forces autoupdates and the latest patch breaks several builds and introduces a few bugs. There is no option on Steam to NOT get the latest updates.If you buy this game on GoG you can control when/if you apply the patches.We're maybe 1/3 through a run and now the rules have changed, making our characters unusable. If we had bought GoG versions we could have rolled back the patch (or chosen not to apply it).======================I've left my original review at the bottom for comparison. The 1st review was at 14 hours this one is at 38 hours.At this point I highly recommend the game esp. for 2-player co-op.We're really enjoying the game now. There is a good mix of storytelling and combat at this stage. This started at about level 5. We're level 7/8 now. We started using the wiki when we were stuck on a quest, which alleviated some of the frustration. We have bought into "using the environment" in combat. Rogue, Knight, Mage, Mage 2 player party. The reading up on the wiki re: traits, skills, abilities was very helpful. Mainly though it's just getting through the first batch of quests that gets you to level 5 that is the hump. Do whatever you need to in order to get past that (use the wiki, google, etc.) and the game becomes more fun (for folks who like the combat aspect more  than the role-playing).We're looking forward to both advancing the story and more fun combat now.At this point the game definitely was worth the $.======================================================Original Review: Did not recommendSummary: If you played the kind of D&D where your group just talked a lot and made up stories and there was very little combat, you will love this game. If you played the kind of D&D where you lived for the combat encounters and enjoyed the fights and the role-playing was a means to get to the fights and advance your character, you will not like this game.I wish I had read a review like this before buying 2 licenses @ $40 each, so I'm writing this in hopes of helping others with similar tastes.Pros:1. It's got pretty nice graphics and turn-based combat.2. It has 2-player co-op in the campaign.Cons:1. No 4-player co-op. There are mods but the campaign only supports 2 and is not balanced for 4. Opponents do not scale. There are 4 characters, you just can't have 4 players.2. Unlike NWN2, or any other game, you can't join with a different character. The characters are part of the profile which controls the savegame. So if the host started the game w/2 characters set up how he liked, you can't join with your character, you are joining his game and playing one of his characters. You can't ever bring another character to his game.3. Very little action. Lots of hunting around for pieces of information. Really needs a better mix of action and "role-playing". It's very light on the action and very heavy on the running around talkng to NPCs and trying to do puzzles.4. The multi-player dialog was supposed to be revolutionary with both players able to interact with the NPCs instead of one just waiting while the other one does all the interacting. Doesn't work that way. In fact, it's worse because one player interacts with a dialog window while theh other has to read all the dialog in the combat log windows, which is a pain.5. Rogues are silly. Stealth is you with a barrel, bush, or  rock suit on. It's really funny the first few times, then it's just dumb-looking. Your "assassin" looks like a clown.6. Picking up loot, searching crates, barrels, etc. is a pain. See WoW, D3, or NWN2 for systems that are easier and less of a pain.If I'm wrong on any of these points I'll be glad to correct them.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												If you're a fan of Baldur's Gate style games, I highly recommend! Divinity: Original Sin is a breath of fresh air amidst the sea of pandering, feature games that have no soul or balance. I've been playing it two-character coop using the Lone Wolf talent on hard, which actually works much better than I was expecting. I was surprised how fun the coop combat and gameplay is despite the game being turn based, and the difficulty worked out quite well despite the unconventional party arrangement. I was concerned the coop might be tacked on before buying but it's actually very well implemented.The writing and voice acting is very good, the combat is a well-designed evolution of the similar games of old (see: Baldur's Gate), and the questing isn't just an exercise in locating exclamation points.Well done, Larian! Solid game all-around.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												WIth a raft of similar retro style, top down isometric RPG's on the horizon, one of the first (another sucessfully crowd funded seed) has landed ahead of some big competition. This a true throwback to classics such as Baldur's Gate and a reninder how difficult these games could be, especialy with minimal handholding and instruction.If this style of game sounds like something you remember fondly, then DIvinity is going to be worth every cent.The game is rendered in superb art and if you can get your head around the seemingly limitless choices on offer and a high difficluty level then there are simply hours of story, npc's, looting, crafting and monster bashing on offer.Some unual and unique gameplay is on offer also, and the multiplayer co-op feels right at home for the genre..Be prepared to lose many an hour to this game,

												BLUF: This is today's version of Balder's Gate 2 and Icewind Dale.Very indepth and intriguing storyline.Very diverse spell/skill combinationsOpen ended class system for skill pointsStrong use of map/terrain for combatClassic turn based combat and roles for saving throwsDiablo style loot system with random dropsQuests and plot require thought to completeThere are some major flaws that include:Loss of much sleep and deprivationHard to find a good stopping pointSad to know that the game will have to end at some pointTLDR: Buy it, support the developers, worth every dollar.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												10/10. I don't review games often. When I do its useally either terrible or its amazing. This game is Amazing with Amazing. Lets break it down shall we. First of all this game will give you flash backs of Baldurs Gate, yet much more streamlined. The lick and move systems is fluid even in multiplayer and changing between your party members is a snap. Combat is amazing too. Its set up in action points. So to do something, like walk you need so many action points to get from point A to point B. Special Abilities, Spells and other things also require these action points. This makes it feel like an actual D and D game even though its not. Charater sheets are easilly explained and texts explains to you exactly what traits and skill do what. The dialog itself is also amazing, sometimes rediculously funny. The story is interesting as well and side questions are not that big of a problem. Though keep in mind your quick save button (f5) because you will need to save and reload a lot with some of the puzzle and traps. Its not easy, nor his it hard. If you like dialog, lot of it and makes the story much more detailed. All in all this game is worth the full price, so if you get it on sale you've made an amazing purchase. Happy Gaming kids andHAVE A NICE DAY!! :D

								A few hours in, and I love it.  The only thing that could make it better would be to include voice actors.  If you're a fan of CRPG, and miss the classic BG/Torment/etc... then this game should scratch that itch nicely.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												D:OS is my new addiction.  So far, I have equal time spent in both the single player and co-op aspects of the game.  Here's a breakdown:Single Player:+It's nice that both characters are the star here.  One is no more important than the other, and you'll spend equal time commanding/leveling both.  +You can now set the AI up, so this means the characters will respond on their own (corresponding to the AI you gave them), or you can choose to make them have none and you have control.+Control both characters how you want: send one into the battlefield to start a fight, and leave one behind to flank or ambush.  Send one to town to sell while one stands behind to teleport you right back to where you were.  There are even environmental puzzles that make use of this lovely feature. Co-op:+Drop-in/drop-out works effortlessly.+As a strategical turn-based game, it works beautifully co-op.  One controls one character, and one the other, and each take turns and controls their summons and whatnot.  It works SO well... better than I had hoped it would.-BIG CON HERE:  You don't bring your own character into someone else's game- you play their other half.  Basically, unless you are friends with that person, and they will create a character for you around your visual/skill likes, you're sort of their lackey.Overall:The game is beautiful and highly addicting, and adding a friend to the mix only makes this already enrapturing game even better.  The "no hands held" approach to their quests may be off putting to some, but is overwhelmingly refreshing to me in this day and age of huge set piece action and predetermined paths.  I also love the traits that you can pick up through dialogues with your partner and choices made in the world.  And, the best part?  LOOT LIKE A MUTHA!  I haven't had a good lootfest in quite sometime, and this game delivers it hamfistedly.  All of this is the recipe for the perfect RPG/Co-op experience that is well worth the price!TL;DR:There is more game here for $40 than I've seen in some games that are $60+.   If you like loot, and you like RPGs, you will have a ♥♥♥♥ing blast with D:OS.
